Headline: Barron's(3/5) Asian Trader: Don't Rush To Snap Up China's Shares
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   The numbers are in: after last week's carnage, Chinese shares in the Shanghai Composite were down 6% on the week, though it still sat on a 6% gain for the year. The MSCI Emerging Markets index fell 6.7%, for a year-to-date loss of 3.9%.   There was certainly cause for investors to be watchful: India announced a budget where it failed to cut corporate taxes and increased taxes on dividends; hapless Thailand's finance minister resigned. Yet the downturn commenced in China's A share market during a week when most people were celebrating the Lunar New Year and when the government made no big policy changes.   Various theories held that the decline was triggered by rumors that China's chief securities regulator would resign (as of Friday, he hadn't) and that China would impose a capital-gains tax (Beijing denied it), and by a general feeling that stocks, up 130% in 2006, were overvalued. What's true is that the market in the country's A shares is largely closed to foreigners and has bubbled higher largely because Chinese investors have few places to park their money. The market cap of China's A and B shares totals $1.1 trillion, versus $1.04 trillion for the Hong Kong market, and foreign investors can buy only about $9 billion, according to Deutsche Bank.   Hong Kong-traded H shares, the stocks widely held by the emerging-markets mutual funds that U.S. retail investors snapped up last year, also fell last week for a 13% decline this year, though they nearly doubled in '06. Says Mark Headley of Matthews Capital Management: "I was fairly cheerful because I'd been running too defensive a portfolio." Like many other investors, Headley says Chinese stocks are still too pricy -- Mainland shares trade at 37 times earnings, according to Bloomberg, versus 18 times for H shares. Headley prefers "lower-P/E stocks in less-hyped places like Korea." Indeed, Warren Buffett disclosed last week that he'd bought 4% of Korean steelmaker Posco (05490.Korea).   Gary Greenberg of Muse Capital, a London hedge fund, wasn't scooping up Chinese shares, either, but he did buy European and U.S. stocks that fell. "Today there's a better balance of fear and greed in the market," says Greenberg.   What happens now? BCA Global Investors recommends that investors refrain from bottom fishing, given that typical corrections run from two to three months. In fact, emerging-market declines range from 15% to 20%.   Henry Chan of Baring Asset Management runs NYSE-listed Greater China Fund (ticker: GCH) and the Asia Pacific Fund (APB). The second quarter is seasonally a rough one for Chinese shares, Chan maintains. "That's the time for policy meetings," he says, "and the time overseas markets are weak."   Plenty of Chinese shares remain overvalued, including big insurers like China Life and Ping An Insurance, and Chan expects weakness in the second and third quarters. Yet Chan is sanguine about the prospects for Chinese stocks for the rest of the year. China's economy continues to expand at a 9%-plus rate, and inflation, at least in January, was lower than predicted. He forecasts both A and H shares will make money in 2007. Chan's big positions include China Communications Construction (1800.HK), Guangzhou R&F Properties (2777.HK) and Parkson Retail (3368.HK).     Don Lam left Vietnam as a youngster after Saigon fell, or, depending on your point of view, was liberated. He grew up in Canada, became a consultant at PriceWaterhouse, where he helped Franklin Templeton organize its first Vietnam Fund, and now is the managing partner at VinaCapital, based in Ho Chi Minh City. Vietnam was one of last year's hottest plays, up 144%, and during last week's rout was up nearly 6%, for a 53% gain year to date. Its bourse has a market cap of $15 billion, versus $1 billion at the start of '06. Lam has two funds -- Vietnam Opportunity Fund and Vinaland. Both trade in London, at steep premiums to their underlying net asset values.   Investors have worried that investing in real estate will result in a repeat of 1998, when in the wake of the Asian currency crisis, values collapsed and buildings were left half finished. That won't happen this time, maintains Lam (who has bought some of those projects himself).   Land prices are still reasonable, he says; Vietnam has joined the World Trade Organization, with the prospect of a flood of foreign investment; and Vietnam has a youthful, growing population. One of Vina's projects is Hung Vuong Plaza in Ho Chi Minh City, which includes 276 condominiums (80%-plus presold), restaurants, shopping space and a gigantic venue for weddings, since young Vietnamese adore getting married.   The prospects for real estate are bright this year, says Lam, who owns 2% of Vinaland. Indeed, it's "a far better investment" than listed stocks for now. For the rest of the year, Lam expects "one or two small corrections of 10% to 15%...but by the end of the year the Vietnam Index should be up by a healthy margin." Corporate Vietnam will keep raising capital, including blue chips like Vietcombank. Lam forecasts the index, now at 1100, will rise to as high as 1400 by yearend.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Why Clear Channel's Buyout May Go Bust
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   With less than three weeks to go until a vote, Clear Channel Communications faces an uphill battle to win investor approval for a $26 billion leveraged buyout led by a group of private-equity firms.   Several big institutional shareholders, including Fidelity Investments, Clear Channel's largest holder, plan to vote against the deal because they believe the cash offer of $37.60 a share undervalues the company by at least several dollars a share. A rejection of the buyout would send an important message that investors will not rubber-stamp leveraged buyouts that promise to quickly enrich private-equity firms and corporate management teams that participate in the LBOs.   Clear Channel (ticker: CCU), based in San Antonio, is the country's largest radio operator. It also owns 90% of Clear Channel Outdoor (CCO), one of the biggest billboard companies. The parent now has an equity value of $18 billion, plus $7 billion of debt.   The proposed buyout, announced in November, must clear a high hurdle: approval of two-thirds of outstanding shares, versus the more typical majority vote. The vote is slated for March 21.   Fidelity, which holds a 10% stake, declined to comment. But the firm, whose opposition to the deal surfaced in January ("Unclear LBO Path for Clear Channel," Jan. 22), is believed to have turned aside entreaties from Clear Channel to change its position.   Barron's has learned that several other big institutional holders plan to vote down the deal. Moreover, it's estimated that 10% to 15% of shareholders may not vote -- which amounts to a vote against the deal. Combine the opposition of Fidelity and other institutions with those shareholders who won't cast ballots, and the chances of approval look poor.   Other big shareholders at year's end included Morgan Stanley, Boston-based Highfields Capital Management and NWQ Investments. A new shareholder in the fourth quarter, with a 1% stake, is Noonday Asset Management, which successfully opposed a buyout bid last year for radio operator Emmis Communications (EMMS). Noonday couldn't be reached for comment.   It's possible that Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee, the private-equity firms that are leading the planned buyout, may try to salvage the deal by raising their bid. But it may take a significant price increase -- to $42 a share or more -- to win over investors.   An increase any smaller than that might not win over key investors like Charles Mangum, who runs the Fidelity Dividend Growth fund, the largest Clear Channel holder within Fidelity. It's believed that Mangum is firm in his opposition and that another buck or two won't sway him. The buyout firms, for their part, have signaled they're unwilling to raise their bid.   The job of generating institutional support for the deal has fallen on Clear Channel CEO Mark Mays and his brother, Randall Mays, the company's president. The Mayses are being aided by Clear Channel's investment banker, Goldman Sachs (GS), which stands to make a $40 million fee if the deal gets approved.   The buzz is that the Mays brothers are struggling to persuade big holders to back the deal. Some institutional holders aren't happy that the brothers plan to retain their positions if the company goes private. Unlike oridinary investors, they will profit if the LBO proves a winner. They will be able to roll over part of their stock into new Clear Channel equity, and each will get options on 2.5% of the new equity. Their father, Lowry Mays, Clear Channel's 71-year-old chairman and founder, plans to sell his 7% stake in the LBO.   Clear Channel shares now trade around 36.20, at about a 4% discount to the buyout offer. The stock traded as high as 37.55 in late January on hopes for a higher bid from the buyout group. If approved by shareholders, the deal is expected to close by year end. Only holders as of Jan. 22 are eligible to vote.   From almost the moment the deal was announced, there was grumbling from institutional investors that the price was low and that the quick auction process wasn't designed to elicit the highest price. The complaints have grown louder in recent weeks because the value of Clear Channel Outdoor has risen near 28 a share from 21, thanks to brisk demand for billboard advertising. The run-up has lifted the value of Clear Channel Communications' stake by $2 billion, and could be a boon to the buyout firms, which plan to put up $4 billion in equity and borrow the rest, more than $21 billion. On the date the deal closes, the firms stand to earn a quick 50% return on their investment simply from the increased value of Clear Channel Outdoors.   "Clear Channel is worth about $43 a share," says Jeff Jacobowitz, an analyst with Robotti & Co., an investment firm whose clients hold Clear Channel shares. Jacobowitz, who also runs a partnership that owns Clear Channel, says the company "has substantial and valuable assets" and that the buyout price is "way too low." Noting that Clear Channel now is in the process of selling its small-market radio stations, he argues that those asset sales ought to benefit public shareholders, not the LBO operators.   At current prices, Clear Channel Communications' stake in the billboard concern is worth $8.8 billion, or $17.90 per Clear Channel Communications share. That means investors effectively are paying $19 a share for the radio business, or nearly $9.5 billion, based on Clear Channel's 493 million outstanding shares. Jacobowitz calculates that Clear Channel's radio business may generate $850 million in free cash flow this year, producing a 9% free-cash-flow yield. That is much higher than the free-cash-flow yields on such other radio stocks as Emmis Communications and Entercom (ETM).   Clear Channel last week released a slide show that apparently is being used to pitch the deal to investors. It warns that the stock price may fall if the deal is rejected and notes the "challenges facing the radio industry."   It's possible that Clear Channel shares could dip if the deal is rejected as arbitragers sell their stock. But it's every bit as possible that the shares could rally, with investors anticipating that the company will take such shareholder-friendly moves as spinning off Clear Channel Outdoor or engaging in a "split-off" of Clear Channel Outdoor. In a split-off, holders of Clear Channel Communications would have the option of swapping their shares for Clear Channel Outdoor shares.   Clear Channel Communications also could announce a sizable stock buyback from the proceeds of asset sales. If the buyout offer is rejected, the Mays family will have incentive to deliver for shareholders -- namely, to prevent angry institutional holders from forcing out Randall and Mark Mays, whose father founded the company in 1972.   Recent reports by two Street analysts suggest that Clear Channel is undervalued. Victor Miller, a Bear Stearns analyst who has been critical of the buyout, wrote in a client note last week that Clear Channel's radio business is being effectively valued at just 8.4 times projected 2007 cash flow when factoring in the value of the Clear Channel Outdoor stake, deferred tax benefits and other assets. Most radio companies trade for about 11 times cash flow. Put a similar valuation on Clear Channel, and the stock would trade at $44.   Miller noted that "one could also easily make the argument" that the current value of Clear Channel's radio stations is "modest," given its strong market position. Clear Channel has a presence in 88 of the top 100 markets, and four or more stations in 84 of those 88 markets.   Clear Channel lately has been taking bids for its small-market stations, and many investors are betting that Clear Channel gets at least 11-to-12 times cash flow for those stations, providing further evidence that the $37.60 deal price is low.   Merrill Lynch analyst Laraine Mancini wrote in a client note last week that "we continue to believe that Thomas H. Lee and Bain Capital have room to increase their bid." She calculated that the buyout firms could pay $41 a share and still generate a 20% annualized return on their investment.   One of Clear Channel's arguments for shareholder approval of the deal is that the radio business faces challenges. While it's true the industry is mature, it is still growing and is faring better than newspapers, another old-media sector.   Clear Channel's radio revenue rose 7% in the fourth quarter, while operating income increased 16%. The company best- ed the rest of the radio industry, which averaged a low-single-digit revenue gain in the fourth quarter. But investors had no opportunity to question Clear Channel about the fourth-quarter performance or the buyout deal, because the company refused to hold a conference call.   The billboard business, meanwhile, is one of the strongest sectors in media because of its relatively low cost to advertisers, its immunity to Internet challenges and the introduction of digital signs, which promise to increase profits. Clear Channel Outdoor posted a 13% rise in revenues and a 16% jump in profits for the fourth quarter.   At around 28, Clear Channel Outdoor shares trade for 13 times projected 2007 pretax cash flow, a discount to the only other large pure-play billboard operator, Lamar Advertising (LAMR), which commands 16 times estimated 2007 cash flow.   Given the quality and value of its assets, Clear Channel Communications promises to be a huge and quick score for the buyout group if shareholders back the deal. The alternative, a publicly traded Clear Channel, looks like a far better deal for investors. The company probably is worth more than $42 a share now, and bulls argue that the stock could hit $50 in the next two years.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Apartment-House Blues
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jacqueline Doherty   Investors consider AvalonBay Communities one of the best-run real-estate investment trusts in the country. Based in Alexandria, Va., the company owns and builds apartments in markets where it's tough to put up new buildings, including California, Seattle, Chicago, Boston and the regions around Washington, D.C., and New York City.   AvalonBay has earned its glowing reputation by increasing its cash flow at a faster rate than competitors, and its long-tenured managementhas made smart moves, like selling high-priced buildings to overeager condo developers in 2005. Avalon also sports a conservative balance sheet, a rarity among real-estate companies in today's leverage-loving world. Small wonder the company's stock (ticker: AVB) has been on a tear for four years, rallying 340%, to 131, since March 2003.   At that lofty level, however, the good news and then some may be reflected in AvalonBay's shares. Based on a multiple of funds from operations, the industry's preferred metric, the company is among the most expensive names in one of the most expensive stock-market sectors. "AvalonBay is the go-go stock within the go-go REIT sector," says Doug Kass, head of Seabreeze Partners, a hedge fund that has sold short the stock. "Once the momentum comes out of this sector, a lot of investors are going to be heading for the exit at the same time." He sees the stock falling to 110 a share.   The market might have gotten its first taste of such a stampede in the past, turbulent week, not to mention a clear indication of investors' growing aversion to risk, as AvalonBay's shares tanked 7%, compared with a 4% decline in the Standard & Poor's 500.   With interest rates low, money has flooded into real-estate-related assets in the past few years as institutional investors, both here and abroad, seek alternative investments yielding more than bonds. Hedge funds in search of the next hot sector also have arrived. Pension funds alone invested an estimated $59 billion in real estate last year, almost double the $28 billion allocated in 2002.   Individual investors also have fallen in love with REITs. According to Financial Research Corp., REIT mutual funds have almost $78 billion in investment assets today, up from $9 billion in 1999, when the sector suffered its second straight year of outflows as investors turned their attention to tech.   Investors typically value REITs on the basis of funds from operations because that measure adds depreciation to earnings. AvalonBay currently trades for 27 times 2007 estimated funds from operations of $4.83 a share. (The company has given guidance of $4.68 to $4.92 per share for this year.) That multiple is close to twice the growth in FFO, almost twice the price-earnings multiple on the S&P 500 and double the industry's historic average. If the price-to-FFO ratio were to return to its historic range, the shares would be 50% lower.   Many REIT investors traditionally viewed such investment trusts as income vehicles, whose high dividends provided a cushion against stock-price declines. That is no longer true; stock prices in the sector generally have increased at a faster rate than payouts. Avalon's yield, for one, has dwindled to 2.6% from 7% five years ago, and is below the REIT-sector average of 3.3%.   It is also below the 4.5% yield on 10-year Treasury bonds, and isn't much higher than the 1.8% dividend yield on the S&P 500. Among S&P components, General Electric (GE) yields 3.2%, Bank of America (BAC) 4.4% and Pfizer (PFE) 4.6%.   After taxes, the difference is even more dramatic. REITs don't pay corporate tax, so their dividends don't qualify for the 15% tax on dividend income that corporate dividends enjoy. Instead, REIT dividends are taxed at a rate closer to an investor's personal income-tax rate.   Granted, AvalonBay has a long history of confounding skeptics. Its shares were considered rich at the start of 2006, but they subsequently rallied 50%. Likewise, they were deemed overvalued in 2005 -- before climbing 23%.   Among the REIT's many fans is James Corl, chief investment officer for real-estate securities at Cohen & Steers. "The value they've created in their real-estate portfolio has gone up, and that is why the stock is up," he says.   AvalonBay is the largest apartment holding for Cohen & Steers, a New York real-estate investment specialist, in part because Corl likes the company's above-average cash-flow growth, which gives it a price-earnings-to-growth ratio of about 2.2, below the industry average of 3.4.   AvalonBay's CEO, Bryce Blair, 48, points to the company's 2007 forecast for 14% growth per share in funds from operations, rental increases of 5% to 6.5% and growth in operating earnings per share of about 12%, to a range of $3.66 to $3.90.   "We're still optimistic about the stock because of the growth engines for the company," says Blair, who has been with AvalonBay since the company was established in 1993 via a spinoff from Dallas-based developer Trammel Crow, where he previously worked since 1985.   AvalonBay has a high-quality portfolio in the best markets, a $5 billion pipeline of apartment projects in various stages of development, a 15% equity stake in a fund run by its management that buys and rehabilitates apartment buildings, and one of the best balance sheets in the business, with a debt at 19% of capitalization, versus an industry average of about 36%.   While these attributes could help AvalonBay outperform its peers, on an absolute basis the stock could have a tough time as industry fundamentals begin to change. "Multifamily fundamentals are starting to decelerate and that's not reflected in the stock," argues John Stewart, a Credit Suisse analyst who has a Underperform recommendation on the stock. The pace of rental increases is expected to slow from 8% in 2006 to 6% this year. Even then it would be twice the historical average of 3%.   Apartment companies enjoyed pricing power last year because the number of apartments in the market grew minimally in 2005 and '06 as speculators bought apartment buildings and turned them into condominiums. But with the housing market cooling, there is now a glut of condos in certain markets. Folks who are unable to sell their condos are opting to rent them out, which also has increased the supply of available apartments.   "Condos are coming into the apartment market, and combined with slowing economic activity, apartment companies may miss their expected 5% to 7% rental-increase assumptions," says Kass. "If that happens, funds from operations would come in below expectations."   Blair counters that AvalonBay is seeing little pressure from the condo market, thanks to its prime locations and lack of exposure to the weak Sunbelt markets. Bulls also believe the weak housing market will benefit apartment owners, as more people sell their homes and rent, while fewer renters race to buy their dream homes.   Besides the growth of condo rentals, the supply of newly built apartment buildings is set to increase in the next few years. "We're seeing signs of capital moving from the home and condo market into multifamily housing," says Michael Cohen, a research strategist at Boston-based Property & Portfolio Research. "We should expect increasing levels of supply over the next five years and slower rent growth."   In 2005, only 40,409 apartment units were added to the largest 54 markets in the U.S. (That statistic reflects the net number of newly built apartments and the units taken out of the market through condo conversions.) Last year, the number shrank to 13,678, according to PPR. In the prior nine years, net additions to the market ranged between 107,042 and 219,719.   As a result, the vacancy rate fell to 5.7% last year from 7.4% in 2003, and rent growth hit 5.1%, the highest since PPR began tracking it in 1991. At AvalonBay the rent increase was even higher, at 6.3%, due in part to the company's concentration in locations where apartment supply is tight.   Property & Portfolio Research estimates additions to the market will return to historic levels in coming years; in 2011 additions could rise as high as 219,557. The firm forecasts vacancy rates returning to 6.2% by 2011, and rent growth falling to 2%. If these forecasts are on target, they are not factored into the shares of AvalonBay -- or any other apartment REIT, for that matter.   Ironically the building boom in apartments begins just as returns in this market are at a low. Industry players refer to a REIT's yield on its investments as its capitalization, or "cap," rate, a percentage calculated by dividing net operating income by the REIT's enterprise value minus the value of its undeveloped land and properties. Between 8% and 9% as recently as 2001, the cap rate has declined to 4.9% for REITs in general, and 4.0% for AvalonBay, Credit Suisse's Stewart calculates.   When the REIT was added to the S&P 500 index in January, he notes, it sold 4.6 million shares at $129 each to increase its float. The company paid down debt with the proceeds. Because Avalon's cost of equity is so low, the debt reduction actually was accretive to earnings. Equity is normally a company's most expensive funding option, and debt is cheaper.   AvalonBay went public in 1993 as Avalon Properties, with most of its buildings located in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic. In 1998 it merged with Bay Apartment Communities, a REIT with apartments in Northern California. The company's senior management team has been working together for 20 years.   The company has a history of building its own apartment buildings instead of buying them, and currently has numerous projects in various stages of development. "We can create more return for our shareholders by building rather than buying" apartment buildings, says Blair. He explains that buildings constructed by AvaolonBay have a 7% cap rate, higher than the 4% yield on acquired buildings.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Barron's Mailbag: Medical Limits
Story: (From BARRON'S)   To the Editor:     It's advertising, not safety, that needs limits. In his Feb. 19 Other Voices essay ("Even Safety Needs Limits"), Peter Pitts says he thinks that it was doctors' prescribing habits that caused the Vioxx problem. Merck's media campaign is a more logical explanation.   Merck's marketing was so successful that it created a frenzied demand in the large group of people suffering with arthritis. Convinced that Vioxx was a wonder drug, they demanded it and, as experience shows, doctors responded by prescribing it. A sizable portion of people treated with the medication would have been equally well-served on a less expensive and safer alternative.   Marketing to the public is unwise for a drug only recently available for use. Prescribing a newly released drug is inherently more risky than one on the market for several years. A safety database for prescribing a medication needs to be refined after it has been on the market; then advertising to the consumer can commence and close monitoring of advertisements for risks and benefits can begin.     Dr. Ronald Blum   Gainesville, Fla.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:03 ET (05:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Streetwise: Ten Years Later, Little's Changed
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   The stock market entered the year on a roll and notched a rapid series of new highs, hit an air pocket before the end of the first quarter and quickly surrendered a few months' worth of gains in a blink.   The year was 1997. Market commentators back then reacted to a 4% two-day tumble and 5% weekly loss with assertions that the fundamentals remained intact. Sound familiar?   The indexes did indeed recover within weeks, after what became a 9% drop, and melted up through the summer, only to endure a brief but perilous mini-crash in October amid the Asian currency crisis. The March gut check turned out to be a warning shot and not the pivotal test.   It doesn't help to make too much of the parallels between a decade-old patch of market history and last week's 4% scalping of the indexes, which punctuated one of the calmest periods in decades. There are too many differences to catalogue here between then and now.   But human nature remains unchanged, so we can expect the same cycle of soothing assurances, attempts to catch a rebound and premature declarations that all is clear.   The 416-point pasting the Dow took Tuesday and the ensuing three days of tentative, unconvincing rallies and nervous probes lower tempered investor sentiment from a self-satisfied -- but not quite giddy -- condition. Enormous volumes of downside-hedge buying preceded and followed the break, which could mean stocks will be supported at lower levels.   The hopeful bullish analogy to all this could be spring 2005, when fear of GMAC financial distress spread panic about brokers' balance sheets and hedge-fund losses. No shivering skinny dippers back then were exposed by a receding liquidity tide; the watch remains active for any this time around.   But with much pent-up selling after eight straight up months, it's tough to conclude with confidence that the absolute lows have been seen, even if things stabilize in the coming week. Complicating the analysis is the very violence and lopsidedness of the selloff, given it came so close to multi-year index highs. With 99% of all action to the downside Tuesday and volume through the roof, it had the look of a selling climax near the end of a downturn rather than an initial move lower.   That would be encouraging if market rhythms didn't usually require some time for fear to spread and selling pressure to build before a high-probability low was in.   On the subject of market psychology, consider the implications of the heavy focus last week on mechanical or technical explanations for the severity of the decline -- whether Tuesday's glitch in calculating the Dow (by Barron's publisher Dow Jones), or the scarcity of specialists on the increasingly electronic NYSE, or the Big Board's network bottleneck.   The preoccupation with the mechanical scapegoats for the first 3% one-day loss in four years tells us that plenty of folks are looking for ways to prove the selloff was either not "real" or was artificially exaggerated. Similarly, back in the fall, there were active conspiracy theories for why the market kept climbing -- supposedly suspect jobs-data revisions, "rigged" pre-election declines in gasoline prices and such.   Doug Ramsey of Leuthold Research at the time correctly took this chatter as a bullish contrary signal that many investors were sidelined, doubting the rally.   Reached last week, Ramsey said: "Our sentiment work has been eroding for two months, and this drop should help repair it a bit. What remains bullish, however, is the fact that our measures have picked up virtually no distribution of stocks by the smart money. "My best guess is that the 'internal' peak in the market -- when the broad list of stocks tops out -- may have, in fact, been made last week. I think the major market averages will recover to new highs in the next couple of months, but they will be accompanied by a thinning list of leaders. That could set up the sort of classic divergences that would spell trouble for the second half of the year."     Every market break has its own trading cues that help suggest whether a reversal is imminent or a recovery durable. There are some obvious ones this time. The Japanese yen, which is rising, is bad for global liquidity and raises terror about speculators being forced to repay yen loans by liquidating risk assets. Brokerage stocks, off 8% last week, are also intuitive bellwethers. Perhaps only when Goldman Sachs, Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers report earnings next week might any assurance be gleaned that they've averted major losses.   Here's a less-obvious group of stocks -- all 9% or more below recent highs -- that will likely outperform if the liquidity-enabled risk embrace resumes, but won't if it doesn't: Moody's (MCO), Fortress Investment Group (FIG), Google (GOOG) and, of course, the manically traded iShares MSCI Emerging Markets exchange-traded fund (EEM).   ---   e-mail: michael.santoli@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: La Caixa Selects Morgan Stanley, UBS For Asset Listing
Story: MADRID (Dow Jones)--Spanish savings bank La Caixa said late Friday it selected Morgan Stanley (MS) and UBS AG (UBS) as coordinators for its planned stock market listing of industrial assets.   The country's largest savings bank by loans said in a press release that the planned float of its industrial portfolio aims at getting market scrutiny on the management of its extensive industrial assets.   Although savings bank control about 50% of Spanish lending and deposit businesses and have large stakeholdings in large listed companies, they are unlisted, mutually owned entities with limited disclosure mechanisms.     -By Santiago Perez; Dow Jones Newswires; (34) 618 528 681; santiago.perez@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 10:33 ET (15:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Barron's Mailbag: Speaking For Himself
Story: (From BARRON'S)   To the Editor:     Some people may have misconstrued certain comments attributed to me in your Feb. 19 piece on Relational Investors ("Insiders, Look Out!"). My comments relating to Sovereign Bancorp were not made on behalf of the company, nor did they reflect any policy, initiative or objective of Sovereign's board of directors, of which I am a member. In particular, I make reference to the words "...we're getting the bank ready for sale...".     Ralph Whitworth   San Diego   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:03 ET (05:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: S Korea Ex-Vice Fin Min Likely To Head Woori Finance-Report
Story: SEOUL (Dow Jones)--Bahk Byong-Won, former vice minister of South Korea's Finance Ministry, will likely become the chairman of Woori Finance Holdings Co. (053000.SE), local online news provider Edaily reported Saturday.   Bahk emerged as the top candidate for the post at Woori after he was allowed by a state ethics committee to get a job in a private company, Edaily reported, without identifying the source of the information.   Bahk is competing with Hwang Young-Key, chief executive of Woori Bank, and former Woori Finance Vice Chairman Jun Kwang-Woo for the top post at Woori Finance, the report said.   Woori Finance, Korea's third-largest banking institution, next week is expected to announce its new chairman, who will be approved at an annual shareholder meeting in late March or early April, Edaily said.     By In-Soo Nam, Dow Jones Newswires; 822-721-0583; In-Soo.Nam@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 03:48 ET (08:48 GMT)

Headline: Mittel-Hopa Merger Not Yet 'A Done Deal' -Chairman
Story: MILAN (Dow Jones)--The merger between Italian holding company Mittel SpA (MIT.MI) and Italian unlisted company Hopa Spa is not yet a done deal, Mittel Chairman Giovanni Bazoli said Saturday.    "There are still several issues to be solved," Bazoli said when asked about a possible forthcoming board meeting of Mittel.   "The offer is not going to be changed," Bazoli said without further elaboration.   Separately Mittel's vice-chairman, French financier Romain Zaleski, said he expects Mittel to reach an agreement with Hopa shareholders, Italian insurer Unipol Assicurazioni SpA (UNI.MI) and ABN Amro Holding NV (ABN) unit Banca Antonveneta.   "I am positive, I think we are going to reach an agreement," Zaleski said.    Investors are closely monitoring the development of the Mittel-Hopa merger because such a deal would make the combined entity Telecom Italia SpA's (TIA) second-largest shareholder.      -By Sabrina Cohen, Dow Jones Newswires, +39 347 3563 463; sabrina.cohen@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 16:18 ET (21:18 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Tools Of The Trade -2-
Story: There weren't a lot of obvious changes to the site last year because the firm was focused on converting to self-clearing, which gives it more flexibility in routing orders, can help keep costs down and facilitates customized reporting. President David Kalt says self-clearing will be the firm's engine for future improvements.   Still, the firm did introduce a universal account, allowing clients to trade all their asset classes under one umbrella and integrate a futures-trading platform into its site It also added a feature called Chart Patterns, permitting clients to find stocks that fit the technical trends they've specified.   Fidelity, which supports both a Web browser and a software system, has tools for customers who don't venture into the stock market very often, as well as souped-up goodies for frequent traders.   Both the Website and the software have pre-condition features to let investors set conditions for buying or selling. One welcome enhancement is real-time balance and margin information. Fidelity's Open Bond Market site was also enhanced, giving customers access to an expanded fixed-income inventory.   Muriel Siebert & Co.'s SiebertNet is in the midst of an overhaul. We were given access to the platform that will be introduced this month, and our rankings are based on this updated offering. The site has all the tax-reporting tools we've rated highly in the past, plus added trading functionality and options analytics. The options Strategy Builder automatically calculates debit/credit amounts, maximum gain, loss and breakeven points.   Multileg options strategies can be selected; a click on the Trade button leads you to a prepopulated order ticket. Siebert continues to offer a high level of account protection, a choice of high-yield money funds, and personalized service.   TradeKing says that it made 52 site enhancements in its first 52 weeks in business, and hasn't stopped. You can't trade anything exotic here, beyond the usual stocks, options, mutual funds and bonds, but rates are low and there are a lot of great tools.   We like the Profit + Loss Calculator, which enables members to chart the profit and loss potential of trades, and the check-box format for building multileg options strategies. The enhancements made to the technical-analysis offerings, and the wealth of educational material available are also key.   As impressive as many online-brokerage products are today, the business still has its flaws, as was evident in last Tuesday's major market meltdown. Some investors found their broker sites at best slow and at worst completely unable to handle trades amid record volume (see Barron's Online for more). And no matter how great the tools, online trading isn't worth the expense if the broker -- and the trader -- don't bother with education. The "trade-now" mentality that many brokers encourage should be resisted.   And there's one caveat about Barron's rankings: The brokers with the highest-point totals aren't always the best choices for you.   If, for instance, you don't care so much about availability of mutual funds or bonds, but are keen to know about the best execution at the cheapest price, consult the scores for those categories and find your own personal five-star broker.   Whether you're choosing a new broker or evaluating your current one, there are more changes coming this year. Prices, say most execs, can come down a bit further even if they don't drop as steeply as in recent years. And the kind of consolidation that brought TD Waterhouse and Ameritrade together is likely to continue, with the possibility of at least one more big deal in 2007.   Everyone should expect to be asked for more information when requesting a cash transfer or to place an order that's outside their usual pattern: Security on financial transactions is going to tighten further. E*Trade has already added a cash-transfer security measure that requires a customer to wait for an e-mail with a unique confirmation number.   Over time, software- and Web-based brokers may start to look more alike. Brokers of both types need to grow and, increasingly, they're stepping onto one another's turf. Because all of these platforms are improving so rapidly, individual traders have one sure bet: It won't be long until they have access to tools that only professionals use today.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Report: Private Equity Firm Blackstone Top Chrysler Contender
Story: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. (AP)--A private equity firm, the Blackstone Group, reportedly is a leading contender to buy DaimlerChrysler AG's (DMX.XE) struggling Chrysler unit.   The Detroit News said Saturday Blackstone is conducting a detailed analysis of Chrysler's finances and operations with an eye toward making a formal bid.   The newspaper is citing unnamed people familiar with the Chrysler sale process.   Auburn Hills-based Chrysler has declined to comment on speculation about a possible sale.   A spokesman for New York-based Blackstone said he's aware of the report but can't comment.   Analysts said potential buyers include General Motors (GM) and three other private equity firms.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 13:37 ET (18:37 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
