Headline: Airbus CEO Critical Of 'Political Interference'
Story: LONDON (AP)--The chief executive of struggling European airplane manufacturer Airbus has criticized political interference in the firm as it undertakes a contentions restructuring plan.   Louis Gallois told the Financial Times newspaper in comments published Saturday that the countries with a stake in Airbus had all tried to save their own share of the company as it closes plants and slashes jobs. He told the newspaper that "national conflicts are a poison for this company."   "I was very surprised to see that every government - the British, the French, the Germans and the Spanish - were all saying we want the best share of the cake, we want composites and high technology and so on," Gallois was quoted as saying.   "My job was to save Airbus and give a future to Airbus.   "I saw a lot of people wanting the best share of the cake and the size of the cake was not important to them. I said it was most important that in 20 years we still have an Airbus," he said.   Airbus is struggling to find buyers for its much-delayed A380 superjumbo plane. UPS Inc. (UPS) on Friday said it was canceling an order for 10 of the cargo version of the jet, leaving Airbus with no orders for the superjumbo freighter. Airbus still has orders for passenger versions of the A380.   Gallois on Wednesday announced a restructuring plan, dubbed "Power8," that will see 10,000 jobs cut in France, Germany, Spain and Britain and the sale or closure of six Airbus plants.   French unions have called for a one-day strike next Tuesday against the plan, and German Airbus workers may join the strike.   In a separate interview with Germany's Focus weekly, Airbus' German chief executive warned against strikes, saying they would be detrimental to the company in the long term.   "Long strikes would hurt the company and throw us back even farther," Thomas Enders said. "That can't be what the workers want."   Earlier this week, EU Transport Commissioner Jacques Barrot also called for the plane maker to be free of "political interference." Speaking on Europe-1 radio, Barrot said the company has been "paying the high price of bad governance, with the involvement of several governments."   Toulouse, France-based Airbus is owned by the Franco-German defense company European Aeronautic Defence and Space Co. Britain's BAE Systems sold its 20% stake in the plane maker last year.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 12:42 ET (17:42 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Hg Capital Set To Acquire Americana International -Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Americana International, owner of the Bench and Hooch urban clothing brands worn by pop stars Robbie Williams and Liam Gallagher, is set to be sold to private equity firm Hg Capital PLC for an enterprise value of GBP190 million, The Daily Telegraph reports Saturday without citing sources.   It is understood Hg Capital has been in exclusive talks to buy the company, the newspaper says, and that a deal could be announced in the next few days.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.telegraph.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 07:07 ET (12:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) A Return Visit To Earlier Stories: Oats: A Natural Fit For Whole Foods
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Robin Goldwyn Blumenthal   This is the rare case where an acquisition is organic growth: Whole Foods Market's planned $565 million purchase of rival natural food chain Wild Oats is an important step in the popular stores' quest to more than double sales by 2010.   The deal seemed to reawaken Wall Street's taste buds. Buying Oats for $18.50 a share will add 40% more square footage to Whole Foods' (ticker: WFMI) current footprint, on top of the 16% increase already expected from new-store openings.   The trendy Austin, Tex.-based food retailer bought 40% more space for 10% of its enterprise value (stock market value plus debt), says UBS' Neil Currie, one of several analysts who raised their assessment of the stock after the news broke. He now rates the shares, recently changing hands at $47, a Buy with a price target of 60, up from Neutral previously.   The price of Whole Foods shares is slightly lower than when we wrote positively about the company last summer ("Fresh From the Farm," Aug. 14, 2006). The stock subsequently jumped to 65.40, only to retrench because of concerns about a deceleration in same-store sales and the cost of the new-store openings.   But the addition of the 110 Oats stores should help reinvigorate performance. Whole Foods is an old hand at buying smaller rivals and coaxing their pretax operating margins to about 7%, more than double that of conventional markets. "Our sales per square foot are practically 100% higher [than Oats'] and there is no intrinsic reason why . . . we can't get those sales per square foot . . . comparable to what Whole Foods Markets is," CEO John Mackey told investors in a conference call. Boulder, Colo.-based Oats' comp-store sales growth averaged 3% last year.   The new stores will complement Whole Foods' ambitious plans. The 192-store chain plans to add 18 to 20 outlets in the U.S. this year, plus a big new store in London. Jack Robinson, manager of the Winslow Green Growth Fund and a longtime shareholder, thinks the appetite for Whole Foods' natural and organic formats and gourmet foods could sustain as many as 500 stores.   A little further down the road, the new markets should help Whole Foods improve its sales at stores open at least a year. Comp-store sales growth has been running recently at a healthy rate of 7%, but that's off the double-digit pace investors had come to expect. Robinson believes Whole Foods can get the rate back up to 10% in the next four quarters, partly from the addition of Wild Oats. He sees the stock rising 20% to 25%,  again reaching about  60  in the next 12 to 18 months.   The addition of Wild Oats will also help give Whole Foods, with $5.6 billion in fiscal 2006 sales, more purchasing power and thus more flexibility to lower prices as competition from traditional grocers heats up.   Once Whole Foods takes some writedowns on expected Oats store closings, the acquisition will add 10 to 15 cents to earnings by 2009, says Mark Miller, a William Blair analyst who raised his Whole Foods rating to Outperform. Next year, earnings are expected to grow 17%, to $1.68 a share, not counting Oats.   To be sure, Whole Foods may look pricey, particularly in light of its slowing growth. It trades at a premium growth multiple of 28 times next year's earnings, nearly twice that of conventional retailers. Still that's well below its historic average of 35 times, and less than what it was before the shares doubled in 2004-'05. And it's the premier name catering to a wealthy, health-conscious consumer in a niche growing at 13%, compared to 2.3% for the traditional retail sector.   Whole Foods is one of the few companies in the sector "that has a very open-ended growth opportunity," Miller adds. That should sustain investors' appetite.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:11 ET (05:11 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Banca Lombarda, Banche Popolari Unite Hldrs Approve Merger
Story: MILAN (Dow Jones)--Shareholders of Italian mutual bank Banche Popolari Unite SCARL (BPU.MI) and Italian commercial bank Banca Lombarda SpA (BL.MI) Saturday voted in favor of the merger of the two lenders, creating Italy's fifth-largest bank by assets.   With 1,975 branches, the new entity - called Unione di Banche Italiane - UBI Banca, or UBI - will control a 6.3% of Italy's banking market, with a strong presence in wealthy Northern Italian regions such as Lombardy, according to the bank's presentation.   With more than EUR79 billion in customer loans and EUR80 billion in customer deposits, UBI will be Italy's fifth largest bank.   "New financial products will be launched after the IT platforms of the two banks merge by the summer of 2008," director general of the new bank Victor Massiah said Saturday.   In 2006, Italy registered six mergers between banks, of which four, after Saturday's vote, are already effective.   Following the merger with BPU, Banca Lombarda - currently a commercial bank - will become a mutual bank and the shareholders with more than 0.5% will have to reduce their stakes within the next 12 months. Among them also French financier holding company Carlo Tassara SpA.     -By Sabrina Cohen, Dow Jones Newswires, +39 347 3563 463; sabrina.cohen@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 12:34 ET (17:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Two Ex-VW Employees Charged For Role In Corruption Scandal
Story: BERLIN (AP)--German state prosecutors said Saturday they have charged the former head of Volkswagen AG's powerful employee council and an ex-personnel manager with the company for involvement in a corruption scandal.   Klaus Volkert, who headed VW's highly influential employee council for 15 years, faces several counts of inciting breech of trust, while Klaus-Joachim Gebauer, a former personnel executive, is charged with breech of trust, prosecutors in Braunschweig said. They declined to comment further.   Both men face the possibility of a fine and up to five years in jail, if they are convicted.   In January, Volkswagen's former personnel chief Peter Hartz was handed a two-year suspended prison sentence on Thursday and fined $749,000 in exchange for a far-reaching confession, as part of a deal worked out ahead of the trial.   The case suggested a seamy side to the close partnership between Volkswagen and its labor representatives, who under German law sit on the board of directors and must be consulted on major new initiatives such as where to locate new production.   During the trial, Hartz' attorney told the court his client admitted awarding "special bonuses" worth $2.5 million in VW funds to Volkert, in an attempt to curry favor.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 09:45 ET (14:45 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: US Airways To Launch Single Reservation System Sunday
Story: PHOENIX (AP)--US Airways Group Inc. (LCC) hopes a single reservation will help it eliminate a series of issues that have irritated customers since it combined with America West Airlines in 2005.   The test will come early Sunday, when the Tempe-based carrier flips the switch on a reservation system computer that handles both airlines' check-in, frequent flier credits, bookings and more.   Executives at the nation's 5th-largest airline are hoping for a smooth middle-of-the-night transition and business as usual on Sunday.   But earlier efforts to merge parts of the system - the airline combined its two Web sites a year ago - resulted in a host of glitches.   Other airlines also have had problems. When AirTran Airways upgraded its system last summer, it couldn't check in passengers. Thousands lined up at counters at its Atlanta hub, and as many as 15,000 passengers were delayed or missed flights.   Denver-based Frontier Airlines Holding (FRNT) ran into a similar problem the first day it went live with a new system two years ago.   US Airways faces more challenges than its smaller counterparts. For instance, AirTran has one major hub; US Airways has three, in Phoenix, Philadelphia and Charlotte, N.C., plus smaller hubs in Las Vegas and Pittsburgh.   US Airways executives said Friday the company has learned from others' stumbles, doing extensive training and running three trials of the conversion.   "We get to demonstrate that these transitions aren't as big and as difficult as historically has been proclaimed," said Anthony Mule, the airline's senior vice president of customer service.   Mike Boyd, a Colorado-based aviation consultant who has criticized the airline on other issues, isn't betting against them.   "Keep in mind they've been planning this for what, two years?" he said. "It probably won't be noticed."   He hedged his bets, though, noting that computers have minds of their own.   "Computers do not follow the dictates of man. They're like teenage kids," he said.   The airline and its passengers will find out quickly. A preliminary test of US Airways' new system is planned for late Saturday in Las Vegas, where its red-eye flights will be checked in manually during a two-hour computer outage to make the switchover.   East Coast travelers will find out early Sunday if the system is up and running as advertised. Monday's business travelers will put it to the ultimate test. US Airways has about 3,800 daily departures.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 14:56 ET (19:56 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Unit 2 at Susquehanna Nuclear Power Plant Safely Shut Down for Planned Refueling and Maintenance
Story: BERWICK, Penn., March 3 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Operators safely shut down the Unit 2 reactor at PPL Corporation's Susquehanna nuclear power plant in northeastern Pennsylvania early Saturday (3/3) to begin a planned refueling and maintenance outage.     While the reactor is shut down, workers will replace about 40 percent of the uranium fuel and complete an extensive list of equipment maintenance and upgrades.        Unit 1 at the plant continues to operate at full power.     "This will be one of the largest outages we have ever conducted in terms of the amount of work scheduled," said Robert A. Saccone, vice president of Operations for PPL Susquehanna.     "The equipment maintenance performed will keep Unit 2 in excellent condition so that it continues to operate safely and reliably," he said. "In addition, selected equipment will be upgraded or replaced in support of a proposed future increase in the amount of power the unit can safely generate."     The U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission is reviewing a request filed by PPL in the fall of 2006 to increase the plant's total electrical output by about 200 megawatts, which is enough additional electricity to supply 160,000 homes.     Because PPL Susquehanna will be replacing some major components during this outage, it is scheduled to be slightly longer than other recent refueling and maintenance outages at the plant, Saccone said.     Unit 2 is expected to be generating electricity again by the middle of April, before the arrival of summer weather and the resulting increase in electricity use by consumers.     PPL schedules nuclear refueling and maintenance outages at this time of year, when temperate weather reduces electricity use and the demand on the regional power grid is lower. Each of the two units at the Susquehanna plant is taken out of service for refueling and maintenance every 24 months.     The Susquehanna plant, located in Luzerne County about seven miles north of Berwick, is owned jointly by PPL Susquehanna LLC and Allegheny Electric Cooperative Inc. and is operated by PPL Susquehanna.     PPL Susquehanna is one of PPL Corporation's generating facilities. Headquartered in Allentown, Pa., PPL Corporation (NYSE: PPL) controls more than 11,000 megawatts of generating capacity in the United States, sells energy in key U.S. markets and delivers electricity to nearly 5 million customers in Pennsylvania, the United Kingdom and Latin America. More information is available at http://www.pplweb.com          Contact: Lou Ramos, 570-759-2285               PPL Corporation               Two North Ninth St.               Allentown, PA 18101               Fax 610-774-5281      SOURCE  PPL Corporation       /CONTACT: Lou Ramos, PPL Corporation, +1-570-759-2285, or fax - +1-610-774-5281      /Web site: http://www.pplweb.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 08:03 ET (13:03 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Market Watch: A Sampling Of -2-
Story: I'm intrigued by the contrast developing between BoJ and the Fed . . . Out here in the financial markets, however, the conviction grows that the Fed will . . . do anything other than stand pat. Who can forget that this is the same body that accomplished 17 straight quarter-point tightenings between 2004 and '06 and moved the bond market hardly at all?   BoJ, on the other hand, might move the bond market explosively if it were ever to address the carry trade as a policy objective, but markets now take it virtually for granted that the risk of any such undertaking is extremely low. We follow the Fed obsessively [despite its] recent record of not being able to move markets, while we blow off BoJ, which is where the operationally relevant global-yield curve is anchored. Stings like a butterfly, indeed; Rodney Dangerfield should have been chairman.   -- Jim Griffin   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Northwest Airlines Asks For Bankruptcy Extension
Story: MINNEAPOLIS (AP)--Northwest Airlines (NWACQ) has asked its bankruptcy judge to extend the period during which it alone can propose a reorganization plan.   The period is now due to expire March 16, but Northwest wants the date extended to June 29.   During the exclusivity period only Northwest can propose a reorganization plan, which it did on Jan. 12. After the period ends, creditors and others can propose their own plan for the company.   Northwest has says it intends to emerge from Chapter Eleven by the end of the second quarter, which is June 30. The company filed for bankruptcy protection on Sept. 14, 2005.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 10:58 ET (15:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS: Reubens To Sell Chunk Of McCarthy & Stone
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--David and Simon Reuben, the property entrepreneurs, are poised to sell a significant chunk of their stake in McCarthy & Stone PLC (MCTY.YY), builder of retirement homes, The Financial Times reports Saturday, without citing sources.   It is understood, the FT reports, that the brothers are set to sell part of their 32% stake in the company.   HBOS, the Reuben brothers and Sir Tom Hunter bought McCarthy & Stone last year for GBP 1.1 billion with Permira and Barclays Capital PLC (BCS), the paper says.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 06:52 ET (11:52 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Weekday Trader: Alternative-Energy Alert
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Dimitra Defotis   A documentary about global warming and ways to reduce it won an Oscar this year. But not every alternative-energy stock deserves a prize.   Despite political support for cleaner-burning domestic sources of energy, the WilderHill Clean Energy Index, a leading measure of stocks tied to increased clean energy and conservation, rose only about 5% in 2006. The index, which has its own exchange-traded fund (ticker: PBW), was up more than 25% at one point last year. But asoilprices fell in the second half, so did shares of alternative-energy plays.   As investors look for alternative-energy companies with staying power, they should be wary of smaller companies with high valuations or a murky profit outlook, even after recent market corrections. Two examples: Ballard Power Systems (BLDP), best-known for its partnership with auto makers to develop  fuel cells, and Canadian Solar (CSIQ), which, despite its name, makes polysilicon-based solar panels in China.   "Too often, alternative-energy stocks become story stocks. The great story can exceed a level that is supported by fundamentals," says James Hansel, a hedge-fund manager focused on energy and technology. "When that happens, it becomes very risky for investors." Fuel cells, pollution-free modules that create electricity with hydrogen, are the big -- and old -- story for Ballard Power, which has a stock-market value of $672 million. But fuel-cell cars aren't likely to be in showrooms before 2014.   Ballard acknowledges that it probably won't turn a profit for years. Partnerships with Ford (F) and DaimlerChrysler (DCX) periodically jump-start its shares. But there's more near-term promise in nonautomotive applications, ranging from residential power and heat generation to heavy-duty transportation, according to National Bank Financial. Still, Ballard is expected to lose 54 cents a share in 2007, and its stock trades at 2.3 times book value, according to Thomson Financial/Baseline. In 2000, Ballard shares fetched almost $145. Now, they're near $6 and could sink to $4 in a year or two, asserts Mark Cox, a manager of the New Energy Fund, a New York alternative-energy hedge fund.   "Other companies have technology," says Cox, who recently made a tidy profit betting that Ballard stock would swoon. "The likelihood that [Ballard] can pull the rabbit out of the hat now -- cut costs by 10 times to be competitive -- is low." In fact, says company spokeswoman Michelle Cormack, Ballard's auto fuel cell operates at just over twice the cost of an internal-combustion engine, adding that Ballard hopes to consume half the cash this year that it did in 2005.   Canadian Solar could turn a 55-cent profit in 2007, according to Thomson Financial. Though the company is incorporated in Canada, its main offices are in Jiangsu, China, where it produces panels, made up of solar cells that convert sunlight into electricity for various commercial and residential uses. Most of its customers are in Germany. This year, the company is beginning to make solar cells, too.   Despite last week's sell-off in Chinese stocks, Canadian Solar, now around 10, still looks expensive, trading at about 19 times 2007 earnings estimates. The company has a market capitalization around $300 million. Some analysts expect Canadian Solar's earnings to jump considerably in 2008, but that's far from a certainty, and Piper Jaffray analyst Jesse Pichel prefers other solar plays.   Canadian Solar says it has locked in several long-term contracts for polysilicon, a crucial solar-panel material in short supply globally. But, Pichel maintains, it's unclear whether it will get enough to meet its aggressive growth plans. And the company needs to diversify its customer base, he says.   Canadian Solar CEO Shawn Qu says his new cell-manufacturing lines, while not in full production, are ahead of schedule and "the company is looking at accelerating installation" of additional lines. Just how the company is doing should become clearer on March 14, when it reports earnings.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Spanish Regulator Fines Deutsche Bk EUR1M For Insider Trading
Story: MADRID (Dow Jones)-The Spanish stock market regulator, CNMV, fined Deutsche Bank AG (DB) EUR1 million for sharing privileged information with investors about Ebro Puleva SA, according to Friday's edition of Spain's State Bulletin, BOE.   In addition, Deutsche Bank will be banned from accelerated book building of Spanish shares for the next three months.   The CNMV levied the sanctions for giving some investors market-sensitive information before Deutsche Bank sold a stake in the Spanish food group Ebro Puleva in 2004.   The sanctions are the latest in a string of regulatory setbacks into trades handled by the bank. Last year, France's stock market regulator held a hearing to consider its recommendation that Deutsche Bank be fined EUR1.5 million for its handling of a 2002 issue of convertible bonds in Alcatel, the telecom equipment group.   Also last year, U.K.'s Financial Services Authority fined Deutsche Bank GBP6.4 million for its actions while placing a large block of shares in Scania, the Swedish truckmaker.     State Bulletin web site: http://www.boe.es     -Madrid Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; (34) 628 278 718     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 08:40 ET (13:40 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Ford In Talks With Prodrive On Aston Martin Bid -Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Ford Motor Co. (F) is in exclusive talks with Prodrive, the motor racing company, over a potential sale of its luxury car division Aston Martin, The Times reports Saturday, citing sources.   Ford has selected Prodrive despite its trouble financing a bid because the racing group has offered a higher price than the other shortlisted bidders; Prodrive's price offer is thought to be close to GBP450 million, the newspaper reports.   One source said however, the Times reports, that Ford hasn't asked for non-public information on Aston Martin to be returned or destroyed, indicating that it is keeping the door open for the other bidders in case Prodrive can't secure its financing.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 06:27 ET (11:27 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) European Trader: Airbus Latest Air Pocket
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Matthew Curtin   Airbus has scored a spectacular goal -- against itself -- in prompting the cancellation of yet another order for its A380 super-jumbo. And the embarrassment comes just when it had thrashed out a restructuring program with its various taskmasters designed to overcome the delays and cost overruns at the multibillion-euro project.   UPS's (ticker: UPS) cancellation of its order for 10 A380 freighters means that Airbus now has precisely no customers signed up for this version of the aircraft; it was originally hoping for around 400.  That leaves the field open for Boeing's (BA) 777 freighter, which will first enter the market in 2008, as well as Boeing's new 747-800 freighter, a direct competitor to the A380.   The Airbus freighter program may now never see the light of day. Fedex (FDX) and International Lease Finance, a unit of American International Group (AIG), had earlier canceled their orders because of worries about whether Airbus could deliver the aircraft on time.   UPS took fright at Airbus' announcement that it had frozen work on the cargo plane to help speed up production of the passenger version of the A380. This came just after Airbus renegotiated a later delivery schedule with the U.S. company.   By delaying the cargo plane, Airbus and parent Europe Aeronautic Defence & Space (EADSF), have, inadvertently or not, gained some short-term breathing space at the cost of overall A380 sales and long-term cash flow. As it is, EADS faces a cash call later this year as restructuring costs and the escalating budget for its new wide-body A350 jetliner strain its finances.   Perhaps this sort of negotiating mishap was inevitable at a time when Louis Gallois, the head of Airbus and co-CEO of parent EADS, has been embroiled in intense discussions with politicians and labor unions about the Airbus restructuring plan, known as Power8.   Gallois has succeeded in pushing through a slightly watered-down program that involves 10,000 job cuts and a thorough reorganization of the Airbus production in France, Germany, Spain and the U.K. But given the labor protests and political outcry that it has caused, particularly in France in the run-up to the country's national elections in April and May, a cancellation from as important a client as UPS is hardly what Gallois was hoping for in his efforts to rebuild investor and customer confidence.     InBev's emergence as the world's best-rated, as well as biggest, brewer looks more justified than ever after its strong fourth-quarter and 2006 results. But that doesn't mean that InBev has a lock on the position.   The Brussels-based InBev (INB.Belgium) reached its target of a 30% margin for Ebitda, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, a year ahead of schedule and with nearly two percentage points to spare.   A combination of strong emerging-market growth and rigorous cost-control generated an 11% rise in Ebitda -- a measure of cash flow -- on a 5.9% rise in beer volume in 2006, with the amount of beer InBev sold up an even better 6.2% in the  quarter.   There were worries at the time of AmBev and Interbrew's merger in 2004 about a lack of geographic overlap and the difficulty of extracting value from Interbrew's activities in mature markets in Western Europe and North America. But those concerns have turned out to be excessive.   Investors may be most impressed by InBev's Brazilian-led management team's success in turning a 0.5% contraction in like-for-like revenue in Western Europe into a 14% rise in Ebitda in 2006.   Credit for that goes to InBev's cost-containment program -- known as zero-based budgeting -- as well as the successful promotion of brands like Beck's, Brahma and Leffe. That offset slack demand for Stella Artois, Interbrew's old mainstay, as beer sales in the region remain sluggish over all.   But serving up another set of such good results in 2007 will prove difficult, though by no means impossible, with InBev's rating at risk of looking stretched.   Before Thursday's earnings-inspired fizz in its share price -- up nearly 3%, to 51.50 euros, equal to $67.80 -- the stock was trading at 17.8 times estimated 2007 earnings, a premium to peers like Anheuser Busch (BUD), Heineken (HINKY) and SABMiller (SAB.United Kingdom) and the median multiple for the sector of 17.2, according to data from InFinancials.   The 2006 performance reflected benefits from soccer's World Cup and favorable currency movements. Those tailwinds will be absent or at best weaker this year. At the same time, it becomes harder to strip more costs out of InBev's business, particularly in Europe, as InBev may have to spend more to keep top-line growth going.   Prudent investors should look for InBev to see its cost-control program through, to show signs it is revitalizing Stella Artois and to pull off more nifty little acquisitions, rather than embark on as ambitious a project as merging with Anheuser-Busch, which agreed in December to be the exclusive importer of InBev's brands.   Enel's raid on Endesa shares is a big setback for E.ON's expansion plans, suggesting the German power company is going to have to look elsewhere to spend its pile of cash.   The Italy-based Enel (ENEL.Italy) this week bought a big minority stake in Spain's Endesa, which E.ON has been trying to buy for 41 billion euros, or $54 billion. As a result, E.ON's American depositary receipts (EON) dropped 9%, to around $43.   Given the complexity of Spanish takeover rules, E.ON now faces a near impossible task in satisfying its own conditions for taking over Endesa (ELE). A deal would require more than 50% of Endesa's shareholders to tender their stock.   If Enel gets regulatory approval to raise its stake to 24.99% from 9.99%, as it wants, that would reduce Endesa's free float to only a little more than 50%. Enel has natural allies among Endesa's biggest shareholders, notably Acciona (ANA.Spain), with its 21% holding, which could stymie E.ON's bid.   E.ON could sweeten its offer without frightening its own shareholders, such is the strength of its balance sheet. But it's more doubtful than ever that money is going to do the talking, such is Madrid's determination to keep Endesa in Spanish hands.   ---   MATTHEW CURTIN is a contributor to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---                           DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES    Region/  Country     DJ Global          DJ Global          DJ Global     Point      Indexes,           Indexes,           Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg.
