Headline: China Shipping Development Orders 6 Oil Tankers For US$307.6M
Story: HONG KONG (Dow Jones)--Hong Kong-listed China Shipping Development Co. (1138.HK) said Saturday it has ordered six oil tankers for US$307.6 million from a Chinese shipbuilder.   China Shipping Development, a unit of state-owned China Shipping (Group) Co., said it would buy the tankers, with each of 76,000 deadweight tons in capacity, from Dalian Shipbuilding Industry Co.   The first of the six new tankers is scheduled to be delivered in June 2009, the company said.   In October 2006, China Shipping (Group) ordered four very large crude carriers from a Chinese shipbuilder, China State Shipbuilding Corp.   China has been trying to reduce the use of foreign tankers for its oil imports, so to help ease concerns over China's energy security and the threat of a global shortage of spare tanker capacity or political friction that could lead to a block on cargo deliveries.     -By Aries Poon, Dow Jones Newswires; 852-2832-2332; aries.poon@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 05:54 ET (10:54 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) The Trader: Why Sensitive Markets May Toughen Up
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   What's in a name? a Manhattan made with Scotch instead of bourbon becomes a Rob Roy, even if Scotch and bourbon are both whiskeys. Wall Street calls a 10% decline a "correction." But does the drubbing that stocks absorbed last week qualify as one -- or is there more to come?   Stocks dropped about 5.5% from their February peak to last week's low, and the selling wiped out the year's gains. The ferocity of Tuesday's beating was plain to see: 99 stocks in the Nasdaq 100fell, along with 498 from the Standard & Poor's 500. The S&P 500 lost $452 billion of its market value in a day.   Blame was ascribed to many culprits, from the selloff in Shanghai to the unsettling remarks from a former Federal Reserve chairman -- but those were more catalysts than causes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average has not suffered a one-day drop of more than 2% since May 2003, and Tuesday's rush for the exit -- bringing a 3.3% loss --  uggests an antsy market waiting for a long-overdue correction.   Wary about waning liquidity --  whether caused by rising interest rates in Asia or a U.S. credit crunch -- and worried that economic growth might slow, investors promptly re-evaluated risk after months of ignoring it. The result was a collective step back from overbought stocks.   The Dow fell 533, or 4.2%, last week to close at 12,114. The S&P 500 lost 64, or 4.4%, to 1387. Those were their biggest weekly percentage declines since early 2003. For both, February marked their first monthly loss in nine months.   Selling was fiercest in high-beta technology and financial stocks. The Nasdaq Composite Index slid 147 points, or 5.8%, to 2368, while the Russell 2000 Index of small stocks lost 51, or 6.2%, to 755. Those were their largest point drops since September 2001.   Violence of this sort, understandably, shakes up the market, and here history may be on the bulls' side. Since 1962 the S&P 500 had fallen more than 3% in a single day 43 times -- yet after 34 of those, the index had climbed higher within 60 days, with an average 60-day return of 6%, says Citigroup.   But have sellers wreaked their worst damage? Defensive put trading surged last week, and the risk forecast measured by the somnambulant VIX volatility index jumped 64% Tuesday -- twice the 31% spike the day after the 9/11 attacks. The volume of index exchange-traded funds -- these are very liquid and can be shorted without a uptick -- increased so much relative to component stocks that the ratio reached a high twice that seen at last June's market bottom.   But any encouraging signs that  bearishness had reached its utmost level were marred by the quick surfacing of hope. The VIX backed off quickly after its spike. Phrases like "buying opportunity," "pause that refreshes," and "fundamentals haven't changed" featured prominently, and too readily, in the ensuing flood of market commentary. Telegenic reporters were invited on air not just to discuss the market, but were prodded for a calming spin.   The relentless slide in brokerage stocks also suggests continued apprehension about subprime contagion -- in addition to a potential ebb in the global-financing boom. Prices of credit-default swaps tied to the debt of Goldman Sachs (ticker: GS), Morgan Stanley (MS), Merrill Lynch (MER), Bear Stearns (BSC) and Lehman Brothers (LEH) -- essentially the cost of insuring against a default by these firms -- have risen in step with concerns about their exposure to credit risk. Subprime loans make up a small fraction of their books, but investors worry about writedowns on loans they fail to resell as appetite for risky debt dies, and revenue is hit by declining mortgage securitizations. Shares of Merrill, which recently paid $1.3 billion for First Franklin, slipped 7.7% last week. Morgan Stanley was off 9.3% while Goldman fell 9.6%.   This week, a violation of last week's lows could still spur more selling, although the markets' confidence should increase the longer stocks stay above those marks. Until then, the markets' sensitivity to economic data will be heightened.   Last week, the Commerce Department said that fourth-quarter gross domestic product had grown by just 2.2% -- down from the 3.5% previously estimated. The accelerated selling after a sharp drop in durable-goods orders showed how a growth scare remains one of the market's dark fears. The economy should grow about 2% this quarter.   But will constricting credit along with tighter financial conditions -- or mere worry about them -- spur more cautious spending? Have these new wrinkles been factored into the economic outlook?   Notably, corporate balance sheets remain shipshape. And an oil uptick and copper prices' first monthly gain in seven months doesn't exactly bespeak fear of a global recession.   The next big test will come soon. "If earnings guidance for the first quarter comes in OK, or above the 5% [profit] growth expected, the markets should start to inch higher," says Peter Dunay, Leeb Capital Management's investment strategist. Until then, some bourbons and scotches may be downed in celebration, others to numb the pain.     When bleeding stocks turn computer screens red across the globe, the smiles only grow broader -- discreetly, of course, since no one wants to rub it in -- at 20 South Wacker Drive in downtown Chicago. That's because the kind of volatility that leaves the financial world reeling often means big business for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME).   As money managers lunged for financial tools to hedge their risk, trading volume surged to new records at nearly every option and futures market. And the CME is the largest of them all.   Consider the difference a day makes: Before last Tuesday, February trading volume at the CME was running 5.1% below levels projected by Sandler O'Neill analyst Richard Repetto, and the futures exchange needed a hefty 22.9% uptick in March trading just to meet Repetto's quarterly target of 363 million contracts.   But on Tuesday, the 13.72 million contracts traded smashed the previous one-day record of 11 million and lifted February volume 3.4% above target. March volume now needs to grow just 5.6% to keep pace -- a cakewalk, considering the clamor for derivatives in this nervous market.   Sure, the boost might prove fleeting, but the effect likely will linger, with once-bitten-twice-shy traders continuing to hedge even after the volatile jag passes.   CME shares traded as high as 596 in late January, but drifted down to 511 amid worries about its ability to meet heightened Street expectations. A 6.6% bounce after Tuesday's selling points to its rising appeal in choppy markets and lifted shares to 545. At 30 times forward earnings, the stock isn't cheap -- but looks less rabidly coveted next to commodity- exchange stocks like Nymex (NMX) and InterContinental Exchange (ICE).   The International Securities Exchange (ISE) also enjoyed a midweek bounce. But its smaller rise reflects the stiffer competition in the crowded options market -- versus the monopolistic stranglehold the CME enjoys in trading U.S. futures -- and the takeover premium already factored into ISE shares.   Across the pond, interdealer brokers like ICAP (IAP.UK) reported record electronic-trading volume. Consolidation has reduced the number of such third-party firms, and the essential service they provide in trading U.S. Treasury bonds and other instruments for investment banks, companies and merchant banks helps ensure pricing power.   Viel & Cie (VIL.France), which owns majority stakes in Lausanne-based brokerage Compagnie Financiere Tradition, and the online brokerage Bourse Direct, also benefits from rising volume. By some estimates, the sum of Viel's parts should value the stock at more than 6 euros -- above the <euro>4.95 they trade at today.     The $45 billion cash-and-debt offer to buy TXU (TXU) -- the largest leveraged buyout ever! -- has hogged headlines all week, but it wasn't the only intriguing deal in the utility world. A $1.6 billion plan by Itron (ITRI) to buy the privately-held Actaris in Luxembourg, announced before trading opened last Monday, was roundly applauded by the few investors paying attention.   Itron makes meters used by electric, gas and water companies. But it is often classified as a technology company because it also provides software and services that let utility companies read meters automatically.   While its home base is near Spokane, Wash., what Itron really occupies is a sweet spot along the utility companies' route to better productivity. Automatic meter-reading technology lets the companies cut costs associated with manual meter reading, and gather timely and accurate data they can use to optimize their delivery of power. Today, only 35% of North American meters are read electronically, says Canaccord Adams analyst John Quealy, and Itron leads this promising market.   Regulations are different across the Atlantic, but the potential for new technology isn't. Actaris has installed more than 300 million meters worldwide, and just 5% of these are automatically read, Quealy estimates, and profits should improve as Actaris incorporates Itron's higher-margin technology.   The merger will create a global leader in next-generation meter technology. It will also be No. 1 for electric meters, No. 2 for gas, and fourth-largest for water.   Integration risk is slim, since the deal reunites Schlumberger's (SLB) former metering unit -- and its management team. "Strategically, it makes sense, too," says JPMorgan analyst Paul Coster, who pronounced the product, geographic and customer mix "complementary."   No question, Itron's fortunes will be hitched to utility companies'. And contrarians have been wondering if the Dow Jones Utility Average's record high, the behemoth TXU deal, and the rash of speculative call buying in PPL (PPL), Mirant (MIR) and Public Service Enterprise (PUB) may prove to be a marker of a utility peak.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:10 ET (05:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Engines Revved
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Christopher C. Williams   Advance Auto Parts is undergoing a tune-up that could rev its growth substantially.   After five years of double-digit profit gains, the Roanoke, Va., auto-parts retailer hit a pothole in 2006, as high gas prices and rising interest rates forced motorists to delay nonessential vehicle repairs. Sales and profits stalled, and the company's shares fell 13% from a high of 44 last March.   But Advance Auto's shares (ticker: AAP), now around 37, could return to the mid-40s in the coming year if management's strategy to curtail store openings, remodel existing stores, reduce expenses and boost margins jump-starts earnings. Sales at stores open at least a year easily could surpass last year's anemic 2.1% gain.   Industry trends are lining up in Advance Auto's favor, as well. According to the Automotive Aftermarket Industry Association, the average age of cars on the road is approaching 10 years, about the time when mufflers begin to fall off and fan belts wear out. Consequently, more motorists are likely to pull into one of the company's 3,082 stores this year, and Advance could enjoy a small pick-up in pricing. The stores are concentrated in the eastern U.S., but dot 40 states.   "The worst is behind the company," says Standard & Poor's analyst Michael Souers. "We expect expense leverage in 2007 as Advance Auto cycles against easier comps [comparable-store sales]."   After dropping 1.5% last year, to $2.18 a share, Advance Auto's earnings are expected to rebound 11% in 2007, to $256 million, or $2.43 a share. Revenue could jump 9%, to around $5 billion, from $4.6 billion in 2006, while same-store sales could rise 3%. In the longer term, sales and earnings per share are likely to grow by low-to-mid-double digits and same-store sales by 4% to 6% a year.   Advance Auto sells everything from filters to fan belts, and batteries to brake pads, mainly to do-it-yourselfers. It's the nation's No. 2 auto-parts retailer, behind Memphis-based AutoZone (AZO). Other big players in the $204 billion retail auto-parts market include O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) and CSK Auto (CAO). That market is revving up by 4% to 5% a year, which should help Advance Auto hit its goals.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: China Netcom End-Jan Fixed-Line Users Down 3.6% From End-Sep
Story: HONG KONG (Dow Jones)--China Netcom Group Corp. (CN), the smaller of mainland China's two fixed-line operators, said Saturday its fixed-line users fell 3.6% over the past four months.   China Netcom had a total of 115.11 million fixed-line subscribers as at the end of January, down from 119.45 million as reported at the end of September, according to the data released on the company's Web site.   The performance was in line with that of its bigger rival, China Telecom Corp. (CHA), which also reported a sharp drop in new fixed-line users for January.   China Netcom didn't elaborate on the drop in subscribers. Analysts say that competitive mobile phone services in China have been taking market share away from traditional fixed-line telecommunications business.   In January, China Netcom added 173,500 new fixed-line users.   It also added 337,900 new broadband subscribers during the month, bringing its total broadband users to 15.42 million as of end-January, the data showed.   Late last month, China Telecom said it added 250,000 customers to its fixed-lines in January. The figure was significantly lower than the 640,000 new subscribers it added to its fixed-lines in December and is the smallest addition since it started reporting the number in December 2005.   China Telecom's total number of customers stood at 223.3 million as of end-January.     -By Aries Poon, Dow Jones Newswires; 852-2832-2332; aries.poon@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 05:02 ET (10:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Italian Fin Min To Meet Spanish Min Over Enel, Endesa -Report
Story: MADRID (Dow Jones)--Italian Finance Minister Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa plans to meet Monday with his Spanish counterpart, Pedro Solbes, to discuss Enel SpA's (EN) recent purchase of a 10% stake in Spain's Endesa SA (ELE), El Economista reports Saturday without citing sources.   Padoa-Schioppa will travel to Spain on Monday, a day earlier than originally scheduled, for a face-to-face meeting with Solbes in the Italian Embassy in Madrid, the paper added.   Last Tuesday, Enel broke into the 17-month-old battle for control of Spanish electricity utility Endesa SA, paying EUR4.13 billion, or EUR39 per share, for its stake, slightly higher than the EUR38.75 a share being offered by the German utility E.ON (EON) in its bid to take over the Spanish company.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.eleconomista.es    -Madrid Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; (34) 628 278 718     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 04:32 ET (09:32 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Cintas Named Best Uniform Supplier in Food Processing Industry
Story: Fifth Consecutive Year Company Tops Food Processing Magazine's         "Readers' Choice" Rankings In "Uniforms" Category  CINCINNATI--(BUSINESS WIRE)--March 03, 2007--   Food Processing Magazine's 2007 "Readers' Choice" results are in, naming Cintas Corporation (Nasdaq:CTAS) the best uniform supplier in the industry. The results mark the fifth consecutive year Cintas received "Golden Supplier" distinction from food industry professionals.     "Cintas can be particularly proud, having won its category all five years of these awards, and always by a healthy percentage," said Dave Fusaro, Food Processing Magazine's editor in chief. He added, "The results are entirely determined by industry professionals with first-hand experience of the winners' products and services."     "Cintas credits this recognition to its tailored approach in serving the needs of customers, offering specialized services to help meet the rigors of food industry environments," said Bill Goetz, Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer. "With Cintas, customers get a variety of trusted services related to sanitation, security and safety, all from a company recognized as the industry leader and endorsed by several leading trade organizations," Goetz added.     To create the "Readers' Choice" list, Food Processing Magazine surveyed their subscribers from 51 categories across the food processing industry. The questionnaire was an "unaided recall survey," meaning participants were free to nominate any company they wished.       About Cintas Corporation:     Headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio, Cintas Corporation provides highly specialized services to businesses of all types throughout North America. Cintas designs, manufactures and implements corporate identity uniform programs, and provides entrance mats, restroom supplies, promotional products, first aid and safety products, fire protection services and document management services to approximately 700,000 businesses. Cintas is a publicly held company traded over the Nasdaq National Market under the symbol CTAS, and is a Nasdaq-100 company and component of the Standard & Poor's 500 Index. The Company has achieved 37 consecutive years of growth in sales and earnings, to date.        CONTACT: Cintas Corporation               Robin Pacey, 513-573-4851               Marketing Manager               paceyr@cintas.com        SOURCE: Cintas Corporation  Copyright Business Wire 2007     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 09:00 ET (14:00 GMT)

Headline: : US FDA OKs Novartis W Nile Virus Test
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     Novartis (NVS) announced Friday that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration has cleared its Procleix Tigris System, the first fully automated nucleic acid testing system, to screen donated blood, organs and tissue for the West Nile virus, according to a press release.   Developed by Gen-Probe and marketed by Chiron, a Novartis business, the Procleix Tigris System provides blood centers a fully automated platform for Nucleic Acid Testing, ensuring rapid delivery of virus-screened blood to hospitals and clinics nationwide. The high-throughput Procleix Tigris System allows blood centers to process 1,000 blood samples in under 14 hours, enabling high volume individual donor testing.   "West Nile virus is a serious threat to the nation's blood supply. With rates of human infection increasing in 2006, reducing the spread of West Nile virus and other infectious diseases is a priority for blood centers nationwide," said Donald Doddridge, President-elect of America's Blood Centers and President of Florida Blood Services. "The ability to combine the Procleix West Nile Virus Assay with the Procleix Tigris System will significantly boost the efficiency of blood center operations without sacrificing the level of blood safety."   The Procleix Tigris System delivers increased throughput capacity through full automation, including target capture, nucleic acid amplification and detection, in a compact-size instrument. In addition, the system's full automation capabilities allows blood centers to increase blood sample processing during high volume or emergency situations, such as during the peak West Nile virus or mosquito season, without the need for additional resources.   "Our goal is to provide innovative and state-of-the-art technologies to blood centers that will effectively safeguard the nation's blood supply against harmful pathogens and improve blood center operations," said Gene Walther, President of Chiron and Global Head of Diagnostics. "The clearance of the Procleix Tigris System is a milestone for the industry and, for the first time, allows blood centers a fully automated nucleic acid testing solution to rapidly detect the West Nile virus, a potentially fatal infectious disease."   The Procleix Tigris System has been utilized by select blood centers nationwide to screen for the West Nile virus under an Investigational New Drug (IND) application since August 2004. Since then, millions of units of donated blood have been screened by the system intercepting West Nile virus-positive blood that otherwise may have infected patients with the virus.    http://www.chiron.com.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 01:04 ET (06:04 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.   Alcatel-Lucent - ALU-NYSE   Outperform - Price 13.29 on Feb. 26   by PacificCrest   ALU won an outsourcing contract with E-Plus, the third-largest mobile operator in Germany. E-Plus is owned by Dutch carrier KPN. ALU will assume deployment and maintenance responsibilities for E-Plus' mobile network. . . [and] 750 employees. We believe the contract is worth several hundred million euros [company would not comment on potential value]. . . . Most of the value created by Alcatel-Lucent merger should come from cost savings. But this win shows the combined company has the solutions and relationships to win deals and drive revenue growth. We believe Alcatel-Lucent beat Nokia, Siemens and Ericsson for E-Plus contract, a strong endorsement of its competitive position. We don't think revenue opportunities from ALU's increased competitiveness are factored into the current valuation. 12-month target: 21.   China 3C Group - CHCG-OTCBB   Buy - Price 5.20 on Feb. 27   by Maxim Group   Ten-dollar target price still based on conservative '07 projections. With the shares trading at only 11 times our upward revised '07 earnings-per-share estimate, we still believe market is underestimating earnings-power capacity of CHCG's fast-growing retail segment, which yields over double the gross margins carried by wholesale, and is likely to increase over time as percentage of overall revenue. A fair but still conservative multiple is 20 times, which would lift the shares to $10. . . backed by both [discounted cash flow] and relative valuation. The [communication, IT, digital] company's liquidity profile. . . is in good standing. Pro forma EPS of 33 cents came in well above company outlook of 27 cents, and our above-guidance estimate of 30 cents.   Edwards Lifesciences - EW-NYSE   Hold - Price 51.21 on Feb. 27   by Lazard Capital Markets   Refrain from adding to positions in EW, as the beneficial impact of the U.S. launch of the company's nonsurgical heart valves is unlikely to create share appreciation until a year prior to 2010 U.S. launch. While we are encouraged by the company's Dec. 8, 2006, announcement that it intends to pursue a clinical-trial protocol without use of the outdated balloon valvuloplasty as a control. . . we believe investor interest is unlikely to build materially until first half 2009.   Edwards' noncoronary stent R.E.S.I.L.I.E.N.T. data suggest that its LifeStent line is likely to achieve [Food and Drug Administration] approval in 2H07. We believe Edwards' recently launched longer-length peripheral stents may help against competitor ev3's Protege peripheral stents. . . . EW is trading at 22 times our 2007 EPS forecast and 18.7 times our forward EPS forecast one year hence (1Q08-4Q08) of $2.74, in line with the multiple EW has typically had on current-year earnings for the last four years. Hence, we believe shares are fairly valued.   Focus Media Holding - FMCN-NNM   Buy - Price 83 on Feb. 27   by W.R. Hambrecht & Co.   Focus Media is the largest outdoor-advertising firm in China. Reiterating Buy and raising price target to 114. FMCN reported good quarterly results and provided strong guidance for full-year 2007, alleviating Q1 seasonal trends. The company also proved that Tier II markets were very scalable, ramping up the sell-out rate to nearly 50% in the quarter. We believe key drivers in 2007 include favorable advertising trends, increased pricing leverage, higher penetration in Tier II markets and expanded platforms for luxury-goods advertisers.   General Electric - GE-NYSE   Buy - Price 35.34 on Feb. 26   by UBS Securities   Upgrading to Buy [was Neutral], reflecting. . . attractive valuation, plus potential for GE's domestic natural-gas turbine business to record stronger-than-expected orders in '07 and '08, which could improve earnings growth in '08 and beyond. We believe TXU [record acquisition private-equity groups] could mark acceleration of corporate actions influenced by environmental considerations, altruistic, economic or statutory. Raising target to 45. . . assumes GE trades at roughly 20% to 25% premium to Standard & Poor's 500 multiple on our '08 earnings estimate.   Guess? - GES-NYSE   Buy Price 82.52 on Feb. 26   by Sterne Agee   Initiating coverage with Buy 100 target. Guess? is at beginning stage of globalization of its strong brand with opportunities to have $600 million to $800 million in sales from Europe over 3-to-5-year period, up from $283 million last year. Opportunities in Asia may be comparable over a longer period of time. . . . Guess sees a 600-to-800-basis-point [hundredths of percentage points] opportunity domestically based on expectations for higher sales productivity. Guess reported earnings for last year more than double the prior year. Guidance for fiscal '08 is for EPS of $3.30 to $3.40, up 17%-21%. We project EPS of $4 for fiscal 2009. . . these estimates could prove conservative. Our 100 target assumes a valuation of 25 times our forward estimate. . . . Guess recently announced a 2-for-1 stock split, which will be effective March 12, to holders of record on Feb. 26.   Libbey - LBY-NYSE   Market Outperform - Price 12.85 on Feb. 27   by Avondale Partners   Libbey is a leading provider of tableware products to the food-service industry. Their products are sold primarily in the U.S., Canada, Mexico, Europe and China. . . through its sales force and manufacturing reps. Raising opinion on LBY from Market Perform to Market Outperform. Raising '07 estimated Ebitda forecast from $100 million to $102.2 million; initiating 2008E Ebitda forecast of $113 million. Raising our 12-month price objective from 10 to 20, representing an enterprise value of 7 to 8 times our 2008E Ebitda.   NetBank - NTBK-NNM   Hold - Price 3.53 on Feb. 27   by Sandler O'Neill   NetBank [whose principal activities include retail banking and mortgage lending] lowered its per share range to a loss of 15-to-35 cents from the prior range of a loss of 8-to-24 cents. In both cases, management commented that it was "biased to the lower end of the range." The prior guidance was from Feb. 21. NetBank had reduced its guidance with each publication of monthly metrics for 4Q06. Management again cautioned that 1Q07 EPS could be below the current range due to efforts to transition its conforming mortgage operation to break-even and the company's inability to recognize tax benefits prior to returning to profitability. The bright spot in the monthly metrics was a 6.3% increase in average assets to $3.948 billion. . . . Maintaining Hold and reducing our price target by 15 cents to $3.55. from $3.70 to reflect the reductions in book value. Our price target is based on a 1.2 times multiple of our projected 1Q08 tangible book value of $2.91.   Safenet - SFNT-NNM   Outperform - Price 27.76 on Feb. 27   by Friedman Billings Ramsey   For 2007, our new total revenue and pro forma EPS estimates are now $319.6 million and $1.31, versus prior estimates of $315 million and $1.22, respectively. SFNT plans to report its 4Q06 results on March 7 after the bell. Upgrading from Market Perform to Outperform. While we recognize the stock's had a nice run the past few months, we believe there's still more fuel in the tank, as the fundamental story should show steady, nice improvement through '07.   Tenet Healthcare - THC-NYSE   Underperform - Price 7.21 on Feb. 27   by Raymond James   Tenet Health reported adjusted 4Q06 EPS from continuing operations of (minus 11 cents), excluding a myriad of one-time items, 8 cents lower than our estimate [consensus= 4-cent loss]. Operating results continued to reflect pressure from weak patient volumes, particularly managed care (-3.6% year/over/year), the leveling off of managed-care pricing increases (+3.8% y/y), and continued weakness in core markets Texas and Florida. Free cash flow from operations was a negative $121 million for the quarter. . . . Management expects Ebitda to range between $700 million and $800 million and EPS from a 13-cent loss to 0 cents. . . . After sifting through Tenet's messy 4Q06 results, we highlight another soft quarter, albeit with some sequential improvements in operating results. Key 4Q06 highlights include the following: (1) Net revenue increased 2.6% y/y to $2.18 billion [consensus=$2.13 billion] on same-facility revenue growth of 2.6%.   XM Satellite Radio Holdings - XMSR-NASDAQ   Market Perform - Price 14.93 on Feb. 27   by Barrington Research   Reported results for the fourth quarter of 2006 suggested a larger loss than we had forecast. However, while a number of key accounts actually showed better than expected experience, several one-time items in the fourth quarter contributed to a loss per share of 90 cents. . . . XM ended 2006 with 7.6 million subscribers...[versus] initial targets of roughly nine million subs. . . . Management put off most discussion of the proposed XM/Sirius merger specifics, stressing that the companies continue to operate as if the merger will not take place. Maintaining Market Perform.   Weingarten Realty Investors - WRI-NYSE   Neutral - Price 50.30 on Feb. 27   by Hilliard Lyons   Maintaining our '07 funds-from-operations estimate of $3.02 a share, which equates to a 6.7% increase over 2006's results. . . . WRI's refocused strategy could potentially achieve a higher growth rate in '08. Management commented that an 8% to 10% annual growth rate beginning in 2008 is a target. . . . At 16.7 times our 2007 FFO forecast, WRI's stock trades at a noticeable discount to other retail-shopping-center REITs we track for comparison.   ---   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:10 ET (05:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Market Watch: A Sampling Of Advisory Opinion
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   Plunging in Sync     Sectors and Styles Quick Note   by Blue Marble Research   P.O. Box 219, Cross River, N.Y. 10518     Feb. 28: Globalization has changed everything; it's the most important theme of our times. Its impact is and will be felt across all aspects of life, business, and money.   For the most part, its impact has been for the collective good. Increased market opportunities, lower cost of production, etc. But yesterday's synchronized plunge reveals one facet of the downside risks of globalization: The free flow of capital and the interrelated nature of economies, which has produced years of prosperity, wreaked havoc on the financial markets. It's as though Goldilocks turned into the Bride of Frankenstein! At least for a day.   -- Vinny Catalano     A Long, Crushing Correction     Stock Market Analysis   by Stock Traders Daily   P.O. Box 475032, San Francisco, Calif. 94147     Feb. 28: The market broke above our longer-term reversal trigger, then reversed back below that level [the week before] last. It broke above this level for about six days, and this is the normal pattern. We have seen this pattern each time the market has peaked or valley'd since 1998. When breaks of these reversal triggers occur, they usually last about six days . . . the market has now begun a decline which will last for the next 10 years.   I know that's hard to believe . . . but this isn't going to be your ordinary pullback. The pullback . . . will last for more than 10 years. It has nothing to do with interest rates or any of the economic data that we hear everyday. It has everything to do with [people's] investment patterns.   The baby boomers are going to crush this market. Your stocks, your mutual funds, your retirement accounts, and all of your real estate, too, needs to be evaluated immediately. [Last weekend, www.stocktradersdaily.com observed that the market had peaked, and it expected the declines from here to crush the market, based on historical comparisons with two other peak/decline scenarios.]   -- Thomas Kee Jr.     China Bubble Shatters     Market Update   by Harris Private Bank   111 West Monroe St., Chicago, Ill. 60603     Feb. 27: The Shanghai Index's biggest blowoff in over 10 years is sending shockwaves throughout the world's equity markets. Clearly, the Chinese equity market was an individual bubble that needed correcting. I illustrated the point last month: The Chinese equity market gained over 80% last year, as 90,000 new trading accounts opened daily. As of last month, there were a total of 80.5 million brokerage accounts, according to China Securities Depository and Clearing Corp. The market is overwhelmingly retail oriented, with individuals comprising close to 98% of trading volume.   That said, the world's highly liquid investment markets are taking Shanghai's plunge seriously. Two of our five liquidity indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500 Volatility Index and the value of the Japanese yen, have spiked, suggesting a pullback in liquidity. While the indicators bear further watching, the Shanghai market is isolated from institutional investors and many of its investors don't have a long enough memory to recall their 1993 boom-bust cycle. I don't expect the misadventures [of] Shanghai to impact the Chinese economy or global equity markets.   -- Jack Ablin     Watching S&P Bottoms     Special Alert   by the McClellan Report   P.O. Box 39779, Lakewood, Wash. 98496     Feb. 27: The extreme events [Tuesday] merit special comment. The decline we witness[ed] caused the S&P 500 to break its rising bottoms line. That is the threshold we have been watching for a change to a bearish stance. We do think that this downtrend break is a bearish event . . . The Fed may even help . . . assuming that [Fed chief Ben] Bernanke has not completely dismantled the Plunge Protection Team.   -- Tom McClellan     Durable-Goods Decline a Catalyst     Economy Strategy   by National Bank Financial   1155 Metcalfe St., Montreal, Canada H3B 4S9     Feb. 27: For many, Tuesday's selloff on Wall Street results from the Shanghai index's 8.8% drop, the biggest daily decline in a decade. However, it would be naive to believe that the Chinese emerging market correction (long overdue after a 130% return in 2006) is the only reason. Indeed, the Wall Street consensus conviction of robust business capital spending and the absence of a spillover effect from the housing recession was [tested Tuesday] after the durable-goods new orders figure was released: 7.8% decline in January.   The nondefense ex-aircraft capital-goods orders, a key barometer of business capital spending, declined 6% in January and fell in the red on a year/over/year basis for the first time since the 2003 Iraq invasion. Bottom line: Since late summer, we've argued that the U.S. economy would experience a bumpy landing in '07 and profits would likely contract as risk-aversion returned.   -- Clement Gignac     It's the Economy     Ritholtz Strategy   by Ritholtz Research/Analytics   300 Park Ave., New York, N.Y. 10022     Feb. 27: Why the drop in China's benchmark stock index on fears of increased margin requirements should impact the U.S. or Europe is food for thought.   Quite frankly, I don't believe it is that.   What's more likely is the growing recognition that inflation remains worrisome, that growth is slowing, and that the subprime mortgage housing debacle will no longer remained contained. . . . Why the economy, and not China? Consider [recent] headlines, dominated by non-China news -- from the Wall Street Journal: Orders for Durable Goods Tumble; Banks Keeping Less Money in Reserve; Default Fears Drain Subprime Pool, Adding to Pressures on Prices; Uncertainty About Fallout on Bonds.   If you want to believe that some bureaucrat in China changing the margin requirements for local speculators is the cause of the U.S. selloff, then go ahead.   I prefer to believe what is right before my eyes: Decaying economic fundamentals, a complacent market that is overbought and way overdue for a correction. Add to that the single biggest positive contributor to the economy over the past four years, housing, showing no signs of being anywhere near a bottom. A few more jiggles on the screen, and there will be significant technical deterioration.   -- Barry Ritholtz     Pretend It's May: Sell, and Go Away     Correction Strategy   by www.valuestocktips.com   2524 Greenhill Trail, The Villages, Fla. 32162     Feb. 27: The good news when the market corrects is stocks that you like and have recently sold off at a profit can start to be bought back at better valuations (but be patient). The bad news is the profits you have in current positions swing to losses and your emotions become your worst enemy.   Let's step back and think about this for a minute. The only thing that has changed in the last week is there is more fallout in the subprime mortgage market and there are some signs of a slowing economy. I expect the economic numbers over the next two days to confirm more slowdown in the economy, and have tried to position my positions for that kind of environment.   My theory has been that the market usually tops in mid-April when [individual-retirement account] contributions roll in, and the market peaks before it struggles every summer. What I think we are seeing now is the market peaking here more in mid-February instead of mid-April because of the seven straight up months we had beginning last August. So if you are an investor who hates riding out a correction and cannot take the pain, I want you to consider the old saying "Sell In May and Go Away" right now. There is still time to sell everything and lock in your profits of the last eight months and just avoid the market for a while. Markets always stabilize and then go up much [more slowly] than they fall in a correction, so the chance of missing a market rebound is low.   For now, I will remain in my more defensive type stocks and patiently look to buy stocks on my shopping list. I'm looking to eventually buy Loews (LTR; a conglomerate in insurance, tobacco and hotels) and CNH Global (CNH; in agricultural equipment). Financial stocks are still the sector with the best relative values in the overall market. However . . . if you want to buy them be careful; let them continue to sell off and then buy positions slowly in portions (not all at once). I like in this area Prudential Financial (PRU), JPMorgan (JPM), Barclays (BCS), Goldman Sachs and Franklin Resources.   Stock model portfolio remains 75% invested (mostly defensive stocks)/25% cash. ETF model portfolio remains 24% cash.   -- Mark Thomas     Dramatic Geometry     BoJ Stings Like a Butterfly   ING Investment Weekly   10 State House Sq., Hartford, Conn. 06103     Feb. 27: If "punches above his weight" is, in British English, a compliment to outsized potency, what can we say about the knockdown power displayed by the Bank of Japan in its policy move last week? Muhammed Ali, a noted American poet, might have said "floats like a massive granite and marble banking edifice-stings like a butterfly."   The BoJ move was dramatic in a geometric sense; a doubling of its target rate is even bolder, proportionately, than anything Paul Volcker used to do back in 1980-'81 when he'd swing the fed-funds target by 300 or 400 basis points at a time. An adjustment from 16% to 20% is nowhere near a doubling, as was BoJ's 25 basis point move last week, to a new 50 basis point target.   But size matters, apparently. The BoJ, in self-analysis, might consider its gesture to be a virile one but it had no meaningful effect other than to reinforce the conviction that the fount of the yen carry trade, and all the downstream carry trades, is in no imminent danger of drying up. Until the relatively rigid, high-saving, geriatric Japanese economy that it is responsible to becomes more dynamic, BoJ has limited scope for action.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Profile: Engineering Nice Gains
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By J.R. Brandstrader   "We were overweighted in technology stocks after their weak 2001 and 2002 [fueling fund's 40% jump in 2003], overweighted in utilities after their weak 2003 [helping 2004's 20% gain], overweighted energy in late 2003 after several years of underperformance [helping 2004 and 2005]," says Costomiris, who is based in Milwaukee but who travels around the country in pursuit of juicy investment opportunities.   As of Feb. 28, the no-load fund (ticker: SMCDX) was soundly beating the Standard & Poor's 500 over 12 months. The fund was up 15.64%; the S&P, 11.97%. Over three years, the fund was up an annualized 13.77%; over five, 14.36%. In the same periods, the S&P gained 9.1% and 6.82%. While Morningstar thinks that Wells Fargo could do more to lower the 1.3% expense ratio, it gives the fund four out of five stars for its five-year performance.   The Wells Fargo fund gets high scores from Lipper for capital preservation and consistent return and total return. Its assets have swelled to more than $1 billion from $30 million when Costomiris took it over in 2001 for Strong Capital Management. Two years ago, Wells Capital Management acquired the Strong group after founder Richard Strong was caught up in a trading scandal.   Five years ago, Costomiris told Barron's that "value investing is about avoiding mistakes." That's why he obsesses over risks -- "the three biggest of which are balance-sheet risk, price risk and expectations risk," says the portfolio manager, who learned to evaluate balance sheets from the legendary Robert Vishny, founder of LSV Asset Management, at the University of Chicago.   "We treat assets skeptically and want to make sure the accounting is proper," he says. "On the liability side, we fixate on debt and treat it the way a bank would treat it. If it looks like banks won't lend a company money if it needs it, we avoid it."   He adds, "We don't really care if a company has a bad quarter." But if a company's cash flow turns negative, he often cuts and runs. Frequent shifts in holdings hurt a fund's tax efficiency; on that measure, Wells Fargo Advantage Mid Cap Discipline gets Lipper's worst score.   A University of Pennsylvania chemical engineer (class of '85), Costomiris has an MBA from the University of Chicago. After graduating, he evaluated institutional money managers for Hewitt Associates, and then joined New Jersey investment boutique Thompson Horstmann & Bryant. In 2001, he went to Strong Capital Management in Milwaukee.   You can take the man out of engineering, but you can't take the engineer out of the man; Costomiris scours balance sheets for subtle stress fractures. "The fastest way from point A to point B is seldom a straight line," Costomiris observes, as he weaves through Manhattan's crowds to get to his next meeting. He, or one of his colleagues, hold sit-down meetings with hundreds of managers each year, at their offices or at his in Milwaukee, where he and his wife, Karen, live with their daughter Zoe, 10, and their hockey-playing son Liam, 7.   "Southeast Wisconsin has long winters, but it is also a bastion of money management. A half-dozen companies come through our offices every day," Costomiris says, as he faces off a bus on 42nd Street. The native New Yorker honed his aggressive pedestrian style while attending Manhattan's Regis High School.   These days, the Wells Fargo fund is overweighted in consumer staples, which trailed the market in 2003, 2004 and 2005 before waking up in 2006. Costomiris particularly likes food-related stocks.   One favorite is Cincinnati-based Kroger (KR). He picked up the stock in the mid-teens, when concern about the threat that Wal-Mart posed to grocers was running high. "Forty percent of U.S. consumers shop at Kroger stores, week after week, regardless of the economy," he says, adding that "increasingly important and profitable private-label brands should continue to help the company stay relevant." The stock has been trading in the mid-20s.   More recently, he purchased shares of Hershey (HSY), at 50. "Everyone is very concerned with slow growth in the chocolate category, as well as the commodity-cost [particularly sugar] headwind, but it is a high-quality and steady growth company," Costomiris says. The chocolatier's shares recently changed hands at 52.90.   Some of his other picks are retreads.   He sold Coca-Cola Enterprises (CCE) in June 2004 at about 30, but repurchased it around 20 the next month. He says the fears about child obesity and commodity prices have kept a lid on the stock, but that the "Coke system, including beverage maker Coca-Cola (KO) itself, are unveiling a new strategy that we feel should allow them to operate and price more efficiently." CCE has been trading at 19.94. Coke is trying to expand its existing light and diet brands in emerging markets. Costomiris picked up William Wrigley Jr. (WWY) last summer, when it sank below 44 on worries about rising sugar costs. He hasn't been buying recently, since it moved a little above that.   Another favorite: Del Monte Foods (DLM), which he bought in the single digits in '02. It "is very well-managed by an extremely cost-conscious team" he says: "It has had to outgrow almost $300 million in commodity-costs headwinds over the past several years." Del Monte recently was at 11.55.   ---   J.R. BRANDSTRADER is a frequent contributor to Barron's.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Plugged In: The Ax On Microsoft Splits
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   When I asked Goldman Sachs' doyenne of technology research Laura Conigliaro if she would miss her long-time colleague Rick Sherlund, her eyes welled up ever so slightly. Little did I know that Conigliaro had a surprise farewell toast planned for Sherlund during lunch just a few minutes later in the midst of Goldman's annual technology conference in Las Vegas. It was unusual to see glasses of champagne poured and consumed, midday at least, at one of these sober-minded affairs. Sherlund, however, was not your ordinary analyst.   He had an extraordinary run at Goldman Sachs (ticker: GS), where he was the ax -- or most influential researcher -- on Microsoft (MSFT) ever since the software giant went public in 1985 (He even performed due diligence on the initial offering). In all, he was voted the top software analyst in Institutional Investor magazine's annual poll 17 times.   Not one for fanfare, Sherlund took the stage briefly to express his gratitude. He was so touched by the gesture, Sherlund deadpanned, that he was going to boycott this week's tech confab hosted by Goldman rival Morgan Stanley (MS). It will be the first time in 25 years (one of them as a banker) that Sherlund can attend another brokerage's shindig. The analyst, a Goldman partner, announced last fall that he was leaving the firm, but it wasn't clear where he was going. As it turns out, he's joining a hedge fund run by New York's Galleon Group, where he will initially focus on software but eventually add other tech sectors. "For a long time, I just wanted to broaden out," Sherlund told Barron's. "You just want to manage money after awhile."   After pounding out some 100 quarters of earnings notes, who could blame him for wanting to try his hand at something else?   Sherlund looks forward to his emancipation from deep dives into enterprise software, and to learning  more about semiconductors, hardware and even non-tech areas of investment. He says he owes some of his success to getting the trends right and having the discipline to stick to his convictions. At the same time, he noted that he wasn't afraid to go Neutral on a stock when things just didn't look right.   Senior departures from equity research aren't all that rare these days as the business wrestles with a new operating model. Analysts are no longer compensated by the investment-banking side of the house, which has put downward pressure on salaries, and regulators have added more bureaucratic burdens to the researcher's daily grind. What's more, analysts are being asked to assume more management responsibilities, which takes time from focusing on company research. Sherlund's former Morgan Stanley counterpart Chuck Phillips was among the first to jump ship, to Oracle (ORCL), just prior to the software giant's takeover of PeopleSoft in 2003. He's now a senior vice president there.   The baton at Goldman eventually will be passed to Sarah Friar, who has been covering infrastructure and security software at the firm for five years. Friar acknowledges that her predecessor's proverbial shoes are as big as they come. "In a funny way, Microsoft is the toughest because Rick will always be known as the Microsoft analyst at Goldman."   Good luck, Rick.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Editorial Commentary: Other People's Money
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Thomas G. Donlan   Private equity? Or public abuse? In a couple of recent cases, the 21st century upgrade of the leveraged-buyout movement ought to be known by a more accurate name, such as "borrowing for bribery."   In one of the most flagrant cases, the Univision television network recently agreed to pay a record $24 million "fine" to the Federal Communications Commission in exchange for the commissioners' getting out of the way of Univision's sellout to private equity firms.   Univision is being penalized for failing to broadcast at least three hours of educational programming per week, and for claiming to fulfill that mandate by broadcasting soap operas with child stars.   Judging from the size of the fine, the FCC thinks this is the worst thing anyone has ever done on television or radio -- worse than the momentary exposure of Janet Jackson's bosom, worse than Howard Stern's language, worse than any situation comedy.   The seriousness with which the FCC viewed the case may be judged by the speed with which it acted. It investigated and deliberated and negotiated for two years. Then, when a group of private-equity firms offered $12.3 billion to buy the network, the case was decided lickety-split, on a cash basis.   In a larger case, TXU, a Texas electric utility, agreed to cancel plans for eight big coal-fired plants in exchange for environmentalists' getting out of the way of a record $45 billion sellout to private-equity firms.   One of the buyers, Texas Pacific Group, is led by a certifiable environmentalist, David Bonderman, who sits on the boards of the Grand Canyon Trust and the World Wildlife Fund. He may simply be using his investors' money to enforce his own ideals -- not a problem as long as the investors get a decent return.   The prospective buyers said that if they were in charge of TXU, they would cancel the controversial plants, back federal legislation to require limits on carbon-dioxide emissions, increase TXU's spending to promote energy efficiency and appoint an advisory committee of environmental groups to work on issues of emissions and global warming.   It has been left to cynics to speculate what the environmental groups are supposed to do in return, but the one thing the greenies can do is lay off the deal -- not criticize it or the companies involved. The difference between this and the old protection racket is the claim that the relationship is one of love and admiration rather than fear and contempt.   Idealists may believe that Bonderman and the private-equity firms are dedicated and enlightened environmentalists; the rest of us should see them as dedicated but not enlightened capitalists. Cancelling the plans may or may not be good for Texas air and it may or may not reduce the onset of global warming, but the cancellation certainly frees up billions of dollars of TXU borrowing power.   If there's one thing that private-equity firms do well, it's pay themselves dividends after borrowing other people's money with cheaply acquired collateral. If some such dividends stuck to the hands of TXU executives, it would provide a private-equity payday hard to imagine in a more conventionally owned utility.   As for the electricity consumers of Texas, the state deregulated its electric-utility industry several years ago. If TXU won't build new plants as they are needed, someone else will apply, and TXU will merely distribute the power to its customers. The new owners of TXU won't have to lift a finger, and they will deny responsibility if Texas ever runs short of power.   The power of equity is an awesome thing, but in these deals it's being misused.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Jupiter Chief Exec In Talks With Candover About Buyout -FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Edward Bonham Carter, chief executive of Jupiter Asset Management, is in talks with Candover Investments PLC (CDI.LN), the London-based private equity firm, to buy out Jupiter from Commerzbank AG (CBK.XE) for up to EUR1 billion (GBP679 million), The Financial Times reports Saturday without citing sources.   Bonham Carter and the management team at Jupiter are also thought to be talking to TA Associates, the U.S. private equity firm, the paper reports.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 05:39 ET (10:39 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Interview: Hermes CEO Takes Steady Route To Expansion
Story: By JOELLE DIDERICH   Associated Press Writer     PARIS (AP)--Hermes chief executive Patrick Thomas is an advocate of Slow Fashion.   At the opposite of high-street retailers who churn out disposable trends, the head of the French luxury goods firm - known for its handbags and silk scarves - has a long-term vision.   "At Hermes, through the philosophy and the spirit of the house, we are about objects that have a long lifespan," Thomas told The Associated Press in an interview.   "Many women own a 40-year-old bag from Hermes and it is still beautiful, and that is a source of pride to us."   Hermes, founded in 1837 as a saddlemaker, makes all its bags by hand in France and offers 30,000 different varieties of leather, colors and hardware. Such is the demand for its famous Kelly and Birkin handbags that waiting lists can stretch up to three years.   This is the case for its Birkin bags in exotic leather encrusted with diamonds, which retail for $105,000-$211,000 depending on the client's specifications. Hermes sold 29 of them last year at its flagship store on rue du Faubourg Saint-Honore.   "Each time someone orders a diamond-encrusted Birkin, it is a unique bag, either in size or in material. You won't find several alike, because these are objects that are almost all unique or produced in two or three copies," explained Thomas.   Though Hermes is known for its craftsmanship and the quality of its materials, it doesn't cater only to the top end of the market. Its entry-level bag, the Ahmedabad tote, retails for around $400 and it offers a wide selection of objects under $130.   This variety of products, which also include perfumes and ready-to-wear designed by Jean Paul Gaultier, helped the company post solid growth in 2006, not only in emerging markets like Russia, China and Taiwan but also in Europe.   "Our mature markets are markets in which we have a lot of space to grow. And of course, there are the new markets, among them China, which is registering tremendous growth at the moment: we are doubling sales almost every year," he said.   The only dark spot is Japan, where the weakness of the yen has considerably dampened the appetite for luxury goods.   "People are sick of seeing the price of luxury goods rise by 10% every year," said Thomas, who took over from his highly respected predecessor Jean-Louis Dumas a year ago.   Revenue at Hermes rose 6% in 2006, slightly held back by the cancellation of certain product lines and the opening of fewer stores in 2005, when the company was gearing up for the management handover.   The principal challenge this year is the depreciation in the yen and the U.S. dollar, Thomas said. But the executive, who is targeting an average annual sales growth of 10% at a constant euro exchange rate, played down the risks to future expansion.   "We are not trying to achieve growth at any cost," he said. "We are not going for size in our markets, we are not trying to become bigger. We are trying to explain what Hermes represents, which is not a luxury firm as such but a house of exceptional craftsmanship."   In line with this philosophy, the brand is treading carefully into new markets.   It plans to open its first store in India next year, two years after rival multinational Christian Dior, and is staging an exhibition of its silk scarves in Peking and Shanghai this year as a prelude to a bigger Chinese sales push.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 07:44 ET (12:44 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Growth Stocks: Their Time Has Come -2-
Story: We are in a static period for a while, but later the price of oil will go higher. For investors, it is a matter of isolating companies that are going to do well because of their own internal set of conditions: Their business is very good and their products are in big demand. Schlumberger is a global oil-services company, and their business is pretty good. Core Laboratories is a Dutch company that does something no other company can do: They have an injection system that helps get more oil out of existing wells and gets oil out of new wells faster. I've reduced my energy exposure, but I still have one; I am much more selective.     Q: What do you like on the alternative-energy side?   A: MEMC Electronic Materials [WFR], which produces polysilicon used in making semiconductor wafers for the solar industry. A couple of years out, should conditions stay as they are, it would appear the company will earn between $5 and $7 a share, up from $1.66 in 2006. The stock is around $52.     Q: There's a controversy about whether there is a shortage of polysilicon or not.   A: I've talked with the buyers and producers and sellers of it, and I believe it. The growth in the area is stupendous. I also like SunPower [SPWR] as both a supplier of electric-power products and also of solar cells, solar panels and inverters. It is a broad-based company, and it is growing at 150% to 200% every quarter. I also like Suntech Power [STP] and First Solar [FSLR] and even Canadian Solar [CSIQ] and Trina Solar [TSL], but some of those have now reached levels where I feel one must pull back and be careful for a while.     Q: You mentioned nanotechnology is still a favorite of yours.   A: I do like nanotechnology. I like Fei [FEIC], which makes nanotechnology equipment. It is the leader in the field, with 70% of the business. It has a very good growth rate; in its most recent quarter, sales were up 41% and earnings were up in a major way. It is not well-known or exploited, yet it is the absolute leader, and it is really just getting going.   Of course, I still like Harris & Harris [TINY], a venture-capital firm for nanotech companies. They have a couple of very good companies in their portfolio, one or two of which I think could go public in the next six to 12 months.     Q: What do you like in biotech?   A: The leaders, from my point of view, are Gilead Sciences [GILD], the No. 1 company in making drugs for HIV and hepatitis B, and Genentech [DNA], which has a very good earnings profile and will have a good showing this year, even though investors were a little unnerved by the competition between two of its drugs used to treat macular degeneration, Avastin and Lucentis.   Avastin is a cancer drug and not approved for macular degeneration, but some use it to treat the eye disease because it costs $2,000 a treatment versus $14,000 for Lucentis, which is approved for macular degeneration. On the surface, they appear to be somewhat the same in terms of their impact. The National Institutes of Health is doing a comparison test of the two, but that is going to take something like two to three years to get done, in my opinion. Meanwhile, Genentech wins either way.     Q: Any others?   A: Another, I think, that will ultimately be a big deal, is Vertex Pharmaceuticals [VRTX]. Information on its hepatitis C drug will start coming out in April, May and June at some major conferences. From all I can tell by talking to people in research areas of some medical institutions, it still appears to have a very good shot, although one must always wait and watch because one never knows for sure how something will come out.     Q: What about technology stocks in general?   A: I like some of the lesser-known technology companies.   I love Focus Media [FMCN], which is an audio-visual display company for advertising in China. This company has grown, so far, over 200% every quarter in the last three quarters and it's a leader in its business.   I also love Voice-over-IP, and there is a company called Synchronoss Technologies [SNCR] that offers software that allows communication-services providers to manage their customer orders. Synchronoss grows about 30% to 35% every quarter and is the absolute leader in the field.   A company that just had a secondary distribution, Riverbed Technology [RVBD], absolutely epitomizes what I'm interested in. This company has been growing between 200% and 500% every quarter. It provides services to improve the performance of data applications in wide-area networks. They have equipment that makes it go faster, and they absolutely lead this business in the U.S.     Q: Are you still a fan of Google?   A: I love Google [GOOG] still. And I love Baidu.com [BIDU]. Baidu has given major competition to Google in China and has gone from roughly 25% to 65% of the market there, while Google's share has dropped from 35% to 15%.   Google owned part of Baidu and, unfortunately, sold its stake because they felt they weren't able to work together. But it is a company that really is dominating the fastest growing market in the world, and it certainly is a good company.     Q: Talk about Google. Do you see any signs of problems there?   A: If it had any one problem it would be that the size of success gradually becomes a bigger problem, because maintaining a growth rate at a very high level is impossible. But they continue to absolutely dominate the market.   They are really first-class. They are cash-rich and can afford to buy into the technologies of companies like YouTube. YouTube has certainly had some controversy over what it shows and over franchise rights, but it is evolving into a good business.     Q: Does Google go up from here?   A: I think it goes sideways for a while longer, then it goes higher.     Thanks a lot, Joe.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining 5% or more of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from Feb. 21 through Feb. 28.   Source: Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     Tiffany & Co. (TIF)   Trian Fund said that, owing to Tiffany's commitment to engage in dialogue with it, it won't seek representation on TIF's board at the annual shareholders meeting. Trian, a hedge fund, holds 7.5 million shares (5.54% of total outstanding).     Eagle Hospitality Properties Trust (EHP)   A group including Chairman William Butler and Corporex Cos. offered to acquire all its outstanding common shares for $10.75 to $11.25 each, in cash. Butler currently holds 4.2 million shares (17.6%).     Catalina Marketing (POS)   ValueAct Capital Master Fund offered to acquire all of the shares it doesn't already own, for $32 each. ValueAct holds 7.25 million shares (15.5%).     Ryerson (RYI)   Owl Creek Asset Management said it supports the directors nominated by another activist, Harbinger Capital Partners, and that it's not confident of management's ability to improve operating results. Owl Creek owns 1.4 million shares (5.3%).     Griffon (GFF)   Barington Capital suggested a spinoff or partial initial public offering of GFF's Telephonics unit, and asked GFF to further reduce costs and increase share repurchases. It called for board declassification and a separate chairman and chief executive. Barington holds 1.5 million Griffon shares (5.07%).     Lodgian (LGN)   Oaktree Capital Management nominated two individuals for election to the board at the 2007 annual stockholders meeting scheduled on April 24. Oaktree Capital holds 2.8 million shares (11.5%).     Pogo Producing (PPP)   Third Point plans to nominate six directors to PPP's board at the 2007 annual meeting, scheduled for May 15. Third Point has 4.62 million shares (7.9%).     Acorda Therapeutics (ACOR)   Third Point called for ACOR's immediate sale, saying the company should forego its plan to partner Fampridine SR, its lead clinical-stage product, only in Europe. Third Point has 2.29 million shares (9.9%).     Laureate Education (LAUR)   Select Equity Group called the $65 a share being offered in a proposed management-led buyout of the company "grossly inadequate." Select Equity urged independent board members to reconsider the planned deal. Select Equity and affiliates collectively own about 3.67 million shares (7.14%).     Lesco (LSCO)   Hawkshaw Capital Management opposes Lesco's proposed acquisition by Deere & Co. (DE) because it considers the $14.50-a-share bid inadequate. Hawkshaw said that, if no alternative buyer emerges with a sufficient bid, the pact with Deere should be terminated. Hawkshaw has 1.25 million shares (13.63%).     InFocus (INFS)   Caxton Associates agreed not to call a special meeting before the '07 annual meeting, and won't engage in any solicitation for board changes. After April 13, Caxton may add two designees to the board. The annual meeting should occur by July 31. Caxton holds 4.4 million shares (11.2%).     Increases in Holdings     Lenox Group (LNX)   Clinton Group owns 1.35 million shares (9.6%) after buying 203,453 on Feb. 16 through Feb. 27 at $3.93 to $5.18 each.     Consolidated-Tomoka Land (CTO)   Wintergreen Advisers boosted its position to 17.4% from 15.8%. Wintergreen beneficially owns 991,651 shares.     Decreases in Holdings     Reliant Energy (RRI)   Glenview Capital Management cut its stake Feb. 16 and 17 to 15.4 million shares from 24.24 million (4.99%).   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(3/5) Speaking Of Dividends: Don't Change That Dial
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   The stock market's dizzying dive Tuesday stole CBS's thunder. Thirteen months after its split from Viacom (ticker: VIA-B), the nation's No. 1 television network posted fourth-quarter profits that exceeded analysts' expectations. The results compared with a year-earlier loss of $9 billion from writing down the book value of CBS's TV and radio stations. The cash-rich company also hiked its common dividend 10% and announced a $1.5 billion stock buyback.   The new quarterly will be 22 cents a share, up from 20 cents. Disbursement is slated for April 1 to investors on the books March 7. The stock goes ex-dividend March 5. Yield: 2.96%. CBS (ticker: CBS) has raised its payout  nearly 60% since becoming a stand-alone company.   "The dividend increase and share-buyback program are a direct reflection of the confidence we have in our ongoing ability to generate strong, healthy free cash flow," declared chief executive Leslie Moonves. "We have a long-standing commitment to return value to our shareholders, and these initiatives are proof positive that we will continue to honor it."   CBS said the buyback will take place this quarter as an accelerated share repurchase "from a financial institution."   Traded on the New York Stock Exchange, the Class B shares set a 52-week high Feb. 14 of 32.27. Their 52-week low is 23.85. Chairman Sumner M. Redstone has more than 70% voting control of CBS via his National Amusements cinema chain, which also controls the new Viacom. Redstone owns roughly three-fourths of CBS's voting Class A shares and 6.3% of the nonvoting Class B shares, making the new dividend worth some $81 million a year to him, and around $680 million to investors overall.   CBS's cash stash approximates $3.1 billion, and the company generated about $1.9 billion in operating cash flow last year. It expects revenue ($14.3 billion in 2006) and operating income ($2.6 billion) to be flat in 2007 because of heftier stock-based compensation expenses, the sale of 39 radio stations and nine TV stations in smaller markets, and the shutdown of its UPN network.   With $1.125 trllion of assets under management, mostly in fixed-income funds, BlackRock (BLK) knows a thing or two about total returns. Tuesday, the New York company sweetened its own quarterly common payout by a hefty 60%, to 67 cents a share from 42 cents. Shareholders of record March 7 will receive the new dividend March 23. The ex-date is March 5. Disbursements were initiated in August 2003. They've been raised every year since.   "The substantial increase in the dividend reflects the transformational scale and financial position of the company since closing our merger with Merrill Lynch Investment Managers in September 2006, as well as our confidence in BlackRock's future prospects," said CEO Laurence D. Fink. That $9.5 billion merger more than doubled BlackRock's size.   After setting a 52-week Big Board high of 180.30 Feb. 9, BlackRock's shares change hands near 160 and yield 1.71%. BlackRock went public in 1999. Merrill Lynch owns just under half of the company, and super-regional bank PNC has a 34% stake.   To build upon its Asian presence, BlackRock is launching an equity team in Hong Kong. It also plans to open an office in Beijing this year and to expand its stake in the South Korean market.   BlackRock expects 2007 earnings of $7.25 to $7.55 a share before special items, which is well ahead of Wall Street's current consensus guess of $7. In 2006, the fund manager earned $322.6 million, or $3.87 a share, versus 2005's $233.9 million, or $3.50. Revenue last year surged 76%, to $2.1 billion.   The world's largest supplier of programmable logic chips, Xilinx (XLNX) hiked its quarterly common dividend 33% Monday, to 12 cents a share -- the third boost since payouts began in April 2004 at a nickel. Yield: 1.87%. The respective payment and record dates are May 30 and May 9. The Nasdaq-listed stock, which trades in the mid-20s, goes ex-dividend May 7. Xilinx also will buy back an additional $1.5 billion worth of its shares.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 03, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
